{'subject': '5 Proxies to Investing in OpenAI', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

To profit from change, we need to increase ownership of disruptive trends.
Today's article covers a question that many Finxters frequently ask:

🪴 [ **Blog** ] [How to Invest in OpenAI?]({Link}) 🌳

While it's not possible to invest in OpenAI directly, the blog discusses five
alternatives:

  * **MSFT** (49% stake in OpenAI),
  * **NVIDIA** (makes more revenue from OpenAI than any other company),
  * **ARKVX** ( _Anthropic!_ ),
  * **META** ( _Llama 2!_ ), and
  * **TSLA** (Optimus!).

Check it out if you're interested in any of those! No financial advice. 😊

Be on the right side of change. 🚀  
Chris

**♥️ Community Corner: Featured Resources**

  * [TradeUnafraid]({Link}) is a trading platform owned and operated by Finxter community member Lee.

Do you want to feature your own startup, YouTube channel, blog, or website as
a [Finxter premium member]({Link})? Hit reply and let me know!

[[Blog] The War between Tech Deflation & Monetary Inflation ⚔️ Puts This

Check it out. It's an easy read with charts, graphs, and stats - and,
hopefully, one or two new thoughts for the weekend!

{'subject': 'Thank you ♥️', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

In the last 137 days, I've sent 140 daily Finxter emails with tech news, LLM
education, Python training, and prompt engineering. Thousands of informational
emails since 2018.

Every day I get a lot of feedback and personal messages from the ~160k
Finxters reading this newsletter ranging from _"F**K Off!"_ to _"Finxter
changed my life!"_

My gold standard is to answer every email eventually, even though it often
takes a few days, so please be patient.

Today, I'd love to get your feedback so we can improve our value proposition
for Finxters like you. If you choose to provide feedback, you can either

  * Scroll through the [old collection of user feedback]({Link}) on the blog, and use the form at the bottom.
  * Rate us in the _"How are we doing?"_ section below, or
  * Hit reply and tell me what you like, don't like, or would like to improve.

If you came for the content, feel free to check out [this new opinion
piece]({Link}) countering traditional investment advice.

Also, if you haven't already, feel free to check out the [Finxter premium
membership]({Link}): we'll soon launch a new course on prompt engineering by
our highly skilled star creator Dirk. ⭐

Finally, we don't spend money on ads - only on things that help you learn
faster like content, OpenAI, or hosting - and rely 100% on word of mouth. I
appreciate all support by Finxters recommending us to their coworkers,
friends, and family members. This made all the difference for us.

I love you very much and I'm grateful for your support, your time, and your
attention. ♥️

Happy Thanksgiving!

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'AI Updates', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})



Hey {User},

Yesterday's [Finxter AI Quiz]({Link}) has been quite well-received.

The average was 67 points. Only 10% of participants answered all questions
correctly. And only 22% got at least 90 points.

My (non-technical) wife, who reads all Finxter emails got 90 points - so you
don't need to be a master coder to become proficient in generative AI.

The most difficult questions seem to have been the following:

  * _What is Huawei 's Pangu AI model known for? _👉 [Learn More]({Link})
  * _What is unique about UC Berkeley 's Starling-7B LLM? _👉 [Learn More]({Link})

I've added the links to the articles, so feel free to read up on those
developments in case you struggled with those questions, too.

Before I'll leave you for your well-deserved Christmas dinner, here's an
interesting resource from Meta I just discovered. You may use it to fuel
upcoming AI conversations with your family:

🎵 [Meta Audiobox Maker]({Link})

Firstly, it has a solid text-to-speech (TTS) model that works quite well on
your custom text.

But I found the interface noteworthy because it allows you to easily create
Audio stories narrated by multiple speakers using a drag-and-drop builder and
funny audio effects.

You can even download the MP3 and send it to your family or friends,
completely free. Could be useful for a last-minute Christmas gift...

I wish you all the best - and thanks for staying with us! ♥️

Be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'GPT-4 Turbo is here (FOMO never stops)', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

I don't know about you, but the constant fear of missing out due to the rapid
acceleration of AI progress is killing me.

Once upon a time, Finxter was about Python education. But all I'm doing this
year is catching up with the daily developments, trying to bring order into
chaos to help you (and me) stay on the right side of change.

It feels like we're in the middle of a slow-motion intelligence explosion. The
singularity is here.

Today, let's check out the new GPT-4 Turbo release, i.e., more powerful
features, a 128k context window (enough to load a 300-paged book into a single
prompt) at an API price that's only one-third GPT-4's!

[[Blog] GPT-4 Turbo: 12 New Incredible Features at a 3x Reduced Price vs
GPT-4]({Link})

Think of all the insane apps you can build now! 👇

As a TLDR, here's the brand-new features of _GPT-4 Turbo_ :

  * Pricing reduced by a factor of 2-3x
  * Context size increased from 8k tokens to 128k tokens
  * JSON mode for controlled output of OpenAI Functions (check out [our course]({Link}) on Functions and embeddings)
  * Parallel and simultaneous OpenAI Function Calls (again, the [course]({Link}))
  * Reproducible outputs and seeds (e.g., to recreate the same image or character in an image for a consistent story)
  * Up-to-date world knowledge (cutoff April 2023)
  * One ChatGPT interface for all modalities (DALL-E 3, image processing, Plugins, Code Interpreter) without needing to select them in the dropdown
  * Acquire knowledge from external (WWW)
  * Image input for OpenAI API
  * New Text-to-speech generation capabilities (this is insane - the voices are like humans!)
  * New speech recognition Whisper 3
  * Introducing _GPTs_

The latter is a whole new rabbit hole to explore: You can now easily create
your own flavors of little AI agents that are specialized for certain tasks.

How? With natural language "programming", i.e., you tell them what to do using
words not code.

Then you can share those agents with the world - the idea is to have an **app
store of AI agents**. And here's the kicker: you'll get a revenue share from
OpenAI based on the popularity of your AI agent.

The latter is still a vision but one that's soon be implemented according to
Sam Altman, founder of OpenAI.

Let me repeat this big idea so you don't miss it:

**OpenAI creates an app store for specialized user-generated AI agents** to
perform any task imaginable that can be integrated into any third-party
service like calendar, banking, email, messaging, social networks,
productivity, e-commerce platforms, ...!

As I said, FOMO is not going to stop soon. All we can do is take one idea at a
time and run with it to see where it takes us. Rinse. Repeat.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'ChatGPT Made This Learning Path for AI Prompt Engineers', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

Several members of the [Finxter Discord Mastermind Group]({Link}) proposed I
put together a learning path for the courses on the Finxter Academy. I'm proud
to say that they proposed ChatGPT would be able to do it. 🥹

Great plan!

So, I used ChatGPT's _"Link Reader"_ plugin to read all courses with
descriptions from the URL [https://academy.finxter.com/]({Link}) and prompted
it to create a learning path for the skillset " **Becoming a Prompt Engineer
and AI developer** ".

Here's ChatGPT's proposed learning path that focuses on developing skills in
Python, OpenAI, and related technologies to master prompt engineering:

**1\. Foundations of Python**

Course: [Master the Single Line First! Top 10 Python One-Liner Tricks]({Link})  
Why: Grasp the elegance and efficiency of Python by mastering the art of
writing concise one-liners.

**2\. Deep Dive into Python Data Structures**

Course: [Mastering Python Lists]({Link})  
Why: Lists are a fundamental data structure in Python, understanding them
deeply will aid in handling data effectively in AI applications.

**3\. Advanced Python Techniques**

Course: [Python Magic Methods]({Link})  
Why: Understanding magic methods will allow you to create Pythonic objects
which can mimic built-in types.

**4\. Mastering Prompt Engineering**

Course: [Mastering Prompt Engineering]({Link})  
Why: Gain foundational knowledge and learn how to leverage language models
effectively.

**4\. Introduction to OpenAI's API and Prompt Engineering**

Course: [Prompt Engineering with Python and OpenAI]({Link})  
Why: Dive deeper into advanced prompting techniques utilizing Python's OpenAI
API.

**6\. Practical Application of AI in Development**

Course: [Non-Hyped Exploration: A Practical Developer's Guide to Using ChatGPT
for Arcade Game Development]({Link})  
Why: Understand practical applications of AI in game development and gain
insights into real-world efficacy of AI tools.

**7\. Building AI-Powered Chatbots**

Course: [Creating a High-Performance Extensible ChatGPT Chatbot in 1
Lesson]({Link})  
Why: Learn to build a powerful and extensible chatbot using ChatGPT and other
cutting-edge technologies.

**8\. Web Scraping for Data Acquisition**

Course: [Web Scraping with BeautifulSoup]({Link})  
Why: Acquire the skills to programmatically extract data from the web, which
can be crucial for training and utilizing AI models.

**9\. Advanced AI Applications**

Course: [Prompt Engineering with Llama 2 - Four Practical Projects]({Link})  
Why: You'll delve into practical applications such as book PDF querying,
payroll auditing, and hotel review analytics.

**12\. Continuous Learning and Application**

Engage in various projects such as [creating a joke search engine powered by
ChatGPT]({Link}), contribute to open-source, and continuously explore
Finxter's new courses and materials to stay updated with the advancements in
AI and prompt engineering.

**Additional Notes:**

Engage in the [Finxter Discord Mastermind Group]({Link}) to share knowledge
and seek support from ambitious, positive-minded coders like you. Ensure to
build a portfolio showcasing your projects and learning journey.

This learning path will teach you the skills to be the core foundation of a
profitable new career in the upcoming decade of rapid change.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

PS: The [Finxter Premium Membership]({Link}) gives you access to _**all**_
academy courses, including the Finxter Mastermind Group on Discord.

We'll increase the price tomorrow (10/05/2023) by 20% to compensate for the
increased costs and inflation.

_**Existing Finxter premium members and members who joined before the price
increase (from $99 to $119) will keep the old prices for as long as they
stay!**_ ✅

👉 [Join today or stay premium to lock in today's cheaper prices for as long as
you decide to stay!]({Link})

{'subject': 'DALL·E 3 Trick: Using Seeds to Recreate the Same Image', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

I love scrolling through the OpenAI forum. In a recent post, I discovered this
weird prompt hack of using seeds to recreate images in the new ChatGPT-V with
image generation:

that resembles an OpenAI API call. The trick is adding a 'seed' keyword
argument (e.g., 'seed=4269') in the JSON-like image prompt.

You can find the specific prompt for copy and paste in the blog.

But here's the kicker: to the best of my knowledge, there's no official seed
argument in the official API. It's an emergent phenomenon of this alien
technology!

every so often, amidst our curious prodding, it sparks to life, unveiling
glimpses of its wondrous, magical capabilities.

🔨🌌✨

Chris

{'subject': 'The King of Prompts 🫅', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User}

Today I spent most of my day learning about [_prompt generators_]({Link}).

A prompt generator is a specialized software tool designed to create high-
quality input prompts to guide the responses of other AI programs, such as
ChatGPT or Midjourney.

Its primary objective is to enhance the output quality of these AI programs,
ensuring more accurate, detailed, and contextually appropriate results.

As coders we’re all prompt engineers and as it turns out, ChatGPT is a great
prompter by itself — let’s leverage its powers to push our prompting skills to

Chris

{'subject': 'Mass Unemployment', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

We've had a few pleasant years with relatively low unemployment rates in the
US, Europe, and Asia.

_**So, nobody is talking about the elephant in the room: mass unemployment.**_

🧑‍💻 [[Blog] The Return of Mass Unemployment – Intelligent AI Bots, Expensive
Capital, and Recession]({Link})

And why should they? There's much more labor than people willing to work.

As long as there are problems, there is an opportunity to work. Because the
nature of work is to solve problems, we will always have problems, so we'll
always have work.

And in a healthy economy, people who solve problems will get paid.

**However, I do think that we're in the middle of a paradigm shift.**

As the Industrial Revolution unfolded in the late 18th and early 19th
centuries, a massive shift occurred, with people moving from rural areas to
cities to work in factories.

This shift was not seamless; many faced unemployment and had to acquire new
skills to adapt to industrial jobs.

I worry that the transitional period may be tough for workers on the wrong
side of change because they can only do work that provides little value if
they don't learn and adapt to acquire new skills.

As a business owner, I'd rather hire one skilled prompt engineer than ten
graphic designers.

The inversion principle suggests that to stay on the right side of change, you
must keep learning and adapting. As you're on the Finxter newsletter, you're
interested in tomorrow's tech skills and motivated to learn and improve.

Just keep it up - and check out the new article above for my detailed thoughts
on this topic.

Be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'Wait... is it sentient?', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

Today's email should be fun and playful: 👇

[[Blog] Is AI Sentient? I Made a Coffee Break Python GPT, and This Happened
🤯]({Link})

This will interest you even if you don't try the GPT yourself. Today, I
figured we'd spend a few minutes on the insane reasoning capabilities
**_within a single prompt reply and without external feedback_** of GPT-4
Turbo (see screenshot):

[![](https://blog.finxter.com/wp-
content/uploads/2023/11/image-82.png)]({Link})

The image demonstrates GPT-4 Turbo’s ability to self-correct through reasoning
within a single prompt response. 🤯 The initial response contains an error, but
GPT-4 Turbo assesses the given Python code without external feedback and
corrects itself.

This self-correction process illustrates a few key aspects of the model’s
intelligence:

  * **Analytical Reasoning** : The model can analyze code and understand the logic behind it. When it identifies that the output does not match the expected result based on the code’s logic, it can deduce the correct answer.
  * **Self-Evaluation** : The model exhibits the ability to evaluate its own responses for accuracy, indicating a form of introspection where it can judge its initial response against the logical framework of the Python language.
  * **Autonomous Correction** : GPT-4 Turbo can autonomously correct its own mistakes within the context of the single prompt without needing external input, which is indicative of advanced problem-solving capabilities.

This self-reasoning ability is significant because it indicates a level of
understanding beyond simple pattern matching or retrieval of memorized facts;
it shows an ability to engage with the content dynamically and logically
consistently.

This technology really is different and special. The emergent properties go
far beyond what you'd expect a linguistic model to produce.

For instance, I watched OpenAI's lead developers presenting the new models -
even they were surprised and couldn't precisely explain why they are as
intelligent and sentient.

[Alien technology]({Link}), indeed.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': "I tried OpenAI's API in async mode", 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

In today's Finxter tutorial, you'll learn how to run OpenAI API asynchronously
in Python:

🔗 [[Blog] Can I Run OpenAI’s API in Parallel? Yes, with Python Async!]({Link})

My main goal with this article is to refresh your understanding of
"asynchronous programming", one of the hidden superpowers that scales the
Internet.

Say you're building a chatbot system using OpenAI's API at the backend. How is
a synchronous versus an asynchronous operation different?

In a synchronous chatbot, when User A asks a question, the system waits for
OpenAI's LLM to respond before handling User B's query. If there's a delay for
User A, User B waits, leading to inefficiencies during high traffic.

In an asynchronous setup, the system simultaneously processes User A's and
User B's questions. Both queries are sent to OpenAI's LLM concurrently.
Responses are relayed as received, allowing for faster, parallel processing.
This ensures timely answers, regardless of query order or potential delays.

There are many subtleties to it but the simple gist is this: Users often want
that a system feels synchronous but we coders implement it in an asynchronous
way so that it scales to not one but many users.

You can copy and paste my code from the new [Finxter blog tutorial]({Link}) to
try asynchronous OpenAI API mode!

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'Community Experiment', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

I just realized that we've been too closed-source from a Finxter ecosystem
point of view.

This Finxter newsletter reaches a community of 160,000 coders, AI enthusiasts,
and tech nerds daily.

But we were using this visibility only for Finxter-related content - even
though the world outside the Finxter ecosystem is much larger.

**If we want to call this a community, we should open up visibility.**

This means that for now, as an experiment, if you are a Finxter Premium
member, you have a special opportunity.

You can share the current project you're working on—this could be anything at
all, any link you find intriguing and believe would interest our community.

**What's on the table?**

Here's a non-exclusive list of links you can share with the Finxter community:

  * Your blog or personal website
  * Your AI startup
  * Your Upwork profile link
  * Your GitHub or portfolio
  * Your YouTube channel

{'subject': "Napkin Math on Human vs LLM Coders' Costs", 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User}

**Human vs Machine coder:** Have you ever wondered _how much a human coder
costs per token_ output compared to a large language model (LLM)?

Let's do some napkin math. 🧮

**Human Coder Costs Per Token:**

The median wage for a software developer in the US is ~$53 per hour.

Assume an average typing speed of 50 words per minute. Let's multiply this
with 125% to get the number of tokens output per minute.

So, with our average typing speed, we get about 62.5 tokens/min as coders, or
3,750 tokens/hr.

$53 per hour divided by 3,750 tokens per hour equates to a cost of about
$0.01413 per token for a human coder. 💰

**LLM Coder Costs Per Token:**

Now, let's compare this with the cost of a large language model, which is
estimated at $0.06 per 1000 tokens (GPT-4-32k)

Simple math shows us that this is roughly $0.00006 per token.

**That's how much difference?**  
👇

So, if we do a rough comparison, a human coder is about 235 times more
expensive than the language model ($0.01413 / $0.00006 ≈ 235)!

235x (!)

That's a significant cost difference! 💸

**Not all is lost though.**

Programmers do more than write code - they design, debug, and communicate.

Most importantly, they _engineer prompts_.

When I realized this napkin math, it became apparent to me that we need to
pivot as coders. In fact, if we manage to become prompters first and coders
second, we'll remain on the right side of change.

That's the mission of Finxter - to help you remain on the right side of
change. That's why we started to push into the LLM educational space a couple
of months ago and we will continue to educate you on the latest LLM tools and
prompting techniques.

To your success! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': "Applying Metcalfe's Law to BTC", 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

I spent four years obsessing about (computer science) graphs.

You know, the data structures with nodes and edges, not the plots. The first
sentence of my [thesis]({Link}):

_"Graphs are fundamental data structures in computer science. Wide-spread
digitization generates massive amounts of interconnected, graph-structured
data [...]"_

Let's have a look at some real-world graphs:

  * In **social media** platforms such as Facebook, Twitter, WhatsApp, and Reddit, the 'nodes' represent individual users, while the 'edges' represent the connections between them, like friendships, follows, or likes.
  * In **neural networks** , like the one used in Tesla's Full Self-Driving (FSD) system, the 'nodes' represent neurons (or processing units), and the 'edges' represent the weights or synapses, which are the connections between these neurons.
  * For the **Internet** , the 'nodes' represent individual web pages, and the 'edges' represent the hyperlinks that connect these web pages to each other.

You can also model financial networks like Bitcoin, Ethereum, or the USD in
graph data structures.

**But why should you care?**

Well, understanding graph properties is not only a crucial skill of _computer
scientists_ (as opposed to _coders_ ), it can make you a lot of money in
investing and business too. 👇

An exciting characteristic of graph-structured systems are **network
effects**. In particular **Metcalfe's Law** : _the value of the overall
network grows quadratically with the number of its participants._

Say you build a social network app with N nodes (=users). There are N*(N-1)/2
possible connections (edges) between those nodes.

The value of a network -- say, the telephone network, Twitter/X, or even
Bitcoin -- is often proportional to the number of possible connections.

For example, consider this example social network

  * **N=1,000** users => **~1 million** connections
  * **N=10,000** users => **~100 million** connections
  * **N=1,000,000** users => **~1,000 billion** (!) connections

The larger your network becomes, the higher the value _per network
participant_. (Read this again.)

We've seen this phenomenon play out in many real social networks.

For example, Meta's annual revenue per user was $5 in 2011 with 0.8 billion
users, $20 in 2017 with 2 billion users, and $40 in 2022 with 2.9 billion
users. As the user growth stalled, so did the revenue growth per user.

Savvy investors model the value of a network using Metcalfe's Law - that's the
only way you could've justified an early investment in Facebook in 2011.

It is tough to disrupt the largest network because it tends to make the most
money per user and can spend the most to acquire each user.

Don't try to compete against the dominating network in your field.

Even if you're Google and you're trying to build your own social network, you
still cannot compete.

Now, the same holds for monetary networks like Bitcoin.

I did the exercise and looked at the dominating decentralized monetary network
Bitcoin through the lens of Metcalfe's Law and network effects:

🔗 [[Blog] Want Exploding Prices North of $500,000 per BTC? "Grow N" Says
Metcalfe’s Law]({Link})

To my knowledge, this is the first attempt to model the Bitcoin price using
Metcalfe's Law by setting N to the number of Bitcoin nodes rather than the
number of wallet addresses. The latter is not an optimal proxy for network
size, given that exchanges may custody BTC for tens of millions of users in a
single wallet.

The purpose of this article is not to provide a definitive answer on how the
number of nodes can be utilized as a trading tool (although it appears to hold
potential). Rather, the aim is to stimulate your thinking. If you find this
approach useful, feel free to conduct your own modeling, research, or
backtesting.

Feel free to share any insight you may have - I'll publish follow-up research
on the Finxter blog and share it here in the community if your insights are
valuable.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'This 1-Min Productivity Hack from 2019 Still Works in 2023', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

I'm a sucker for playing online chess.

Once I start a game on my work computer, my productivity takes a backseat for
the day. There's something about the structured world of 32 pieces on 64
squares that my brain finds irresistibly calming. In fact, any game with a
finite set of squares draws me in.

Years ago, I recognized that to achieve my goals, I had to minimize
distractions on my work device.

I had to shut off the domain _chess.com_. Not only for my Firefox browser but
machine-wide for all browsers, i.e., Chrome, Opera, Brave, and Edge.

And I did. And my productivity came back.

This realization led me to publish this blog article in 2019, which I just
revisited and updated:

[[Blog] How to Block A Specific URL on Windows (No Plugin, All
Browsers)]({Link})

It's still highly relevant if you want to boost your productivity! Reducing
distractions is liberating.

On another note, I've incorporated community suggestions into an article I
shared just a few days ago:

[[Blog] How to Go From $0 to $100k Net Worth in 1 Year or Less (in
Tech)]({Link})

Enjoy today's easy reads. And please don't dismiss these ideas simply because
they appear straightforward. There's beauty in simplicity!

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

PS: Wow, six years of online writing has undoubtedly influenced my choice of
titles... 😅

{'subject': 'Tech investors arbitrage negativity bias', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

The future is bright.

Yet, negativity bias is a well-documented phenomenon in cognitive science:

  * First, things that are more negative in nature have a greater effect on our psychological state than neutral or positive things.
  * Second, stemming from this psychological state of overweighing negativity, media feeds us with more pessimistic views. We crave negativity and, therefore, gladly pay negative media with our clicks and attention.
  * Third, you will be labeled naive when you're crazy enough to share positive expectations. Some research suggests that negative people are perceived as more intelligent, competent, and expert than positive people.

As a result, third-party input data flowing into your brain is biased towards
negativity.

From LLM training, we know what happens with input data biases - they become
output biases ingrained in the neural nets.

But any bias is dangerous: _"What gets us into trouble is not what we don't
know. It's what we know for sure that just ain't so."_ \- **Mark Twain** ✒️

Now, let's go to the more practical applications of this - _**how can we
exploit negativity bias?**_

I think a simple exploit of negativity bias is arbitraging perception and
reality of technological disruptions and exponential long-term trends.

We are famously bad in understanding exponential growth and compound interest.
Exponential trends can easily lead to extreme positive outcomes that are 100x
of what we initially expected.

  1. **Ken Olsen (1977)** : _"There is no reason for any individual to have a computer in their home."_

  2. **Sir Alan Sugar (2005)** : _"Next Christmas the iPod will be dead, finished, gone, kaput."_

  3. **Steve Ballmer (2007)** : _"There's no chance that the iPhone is going to get any significant market share."_

This gross underestimation of exponential disruptions is a huge opportunity
for tech enthusiasts like us.

**We know that costs of AI training reduces by 70% per year, for example.**

So, spending $100 on AI training will get us 10x more in two years.

100x in four years.

1000x in 2030.

The [AI Scaling Laws]({Link}) teach us that neural nets keep improving in
performance as we throw more compute, data, and parameters on the problem.

In other words, the intelligence explosion is unstoppable. Essentially, we
have solved the problem of cheaply scaling human intelligence.

**You can count on it.**

So you better position yourself to benefit from change now before reality has
caught up and change is here.

For example, we don't need to train a single human brain for 30 years,
spending $230,000 to put it through medical school. We still can, of course.

But with LLMs, we can now also replicate this brain 8 billion times and put it
on 8 billion smartphones giving every human access to first-class medical
care, 24/7, basically for free.

When I talk about billions of humanoid bots, self-driving cars, autonomous AI
agents, intelligent factories, replacing inefficient management layers from
companies, automating policy and monetary systems, I need to do it with you as
a fellow tech enthusiast and reader of this Finxter newsletter.

**Because most people outside our little tech bubble don't understand the
extent of upcoming disruptions.**

All of it will happen much faster than 99% of people expect due to the
exponential nature of declining cost curves.

Humanity has woken up dead matter and injected life energy and intelligence
into it. We are in the midst of a giant and literal explosion (see PS below).

The future is bright in every meaning of the word.

Let's be on the bright side of change! 🚀  
Chris

PS: Check out this conversation of Lex Fridman prompting Tesla's former head
of AI, Andrej Karpathy:

_**Andrej** : And so basically, it does seem like synthetic intelligences are
kind of like the next stage of development. And I don't know where it leads
to. Like At some point, I suspect the universe is some kind of a puzzle. And
these synthetic AIs will uncover that puzzle and solve it._

_**Lex** : And then what happens after, right? Because if you just fast
forward Earth many billions of years, it's like it's quiet and then it's like
tormal, you see like city lights and stuff like that. And then what happens at
the end? Like is it like a poof? Or is it like a calming, is it explosion?_

_Is it like Earth like a giant, because you said emit roasters, will it start
emitting like a giant number of satellites?_

_**Andrej** : Yes, it's some kind of a crazy explosion. And we're stepping
through a explosion and we're like living day to day and it doesn't look like
it. I saw a very cool animation of Earth and life on Earth and basically
nothing happens for a long time and then the last like 2 seconds, like
basically cities and everything and the lower orbit just gets cluttered and
just the whole thing happens in the last 2 seconds and you're like, this is
exploding, this is a state of explosion._

_**Lex** : So if you play, yeah, yeah, if you play it at normal speed, it'll
just look like an explosion._

_**Andrej** : It's a firecracker, we're living in a firecracker._

_**Lex** : Where it's going to start emitting all kinds of interesting things.
And then, so explosion doesn't, it might actually look like a little explosion
with lights and fire and energy emitted, all that kind of stuff, but when you
look inside the details of the explosion, there's actual complexity happening
where there's like, yeah, human life or some kind of life._

_**Andrej** : We hope it's not a destructive firecracker. It's kind of like a

{'subject': 'The Mathematics of Scalable Wealth', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

I try to focus our Finxter Academy on exponential technologies.

**What are exponential technologies?** I define them as technologies,
products, and services in major long-term growth markets likely to grow
double-digit percentage points (>>10%) annually for a decade or more.

The underlying growth engine of these markets is not marketing or business
savvy but **_efficiencies of scale_** , _**network effects**_ , and
_**technological advancements**_ and breakthroughs.

Adoption tends to happen gradually, then suddenly.

Primary examples of these booming long-term growth markets are [alien
technology]({Link}) (ChatGPT), AI training (NVidia, Tesla), Bitcoin, and
freelance/remote work.

Simple insights like these will be the source of much of the newly-created
wealth:

  * Will there be more or less AI in our everyday lives in 2030? More!
  * Will the demand/supply ratio be higher or lower in Bitcoin? Much higher!
  * Will there be more or less freelancing and remote work? More!

So, as many Finxters clicked on yesterday's article on the salary expectations
of prompt engineers, I thought I'd follow up with a special freebie, i.e.,

timeless principles of wealth: increase units sold and profit per unit. The

{'subject': 'The Big Work Migration Has Begun (Billions Leave Their Jobs)', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

In 2016, I started my online business selling time for money on the free
market as a freelance developer.

Back then, all of my colleagues planned to work in the automotive industry:
seemingly a bright and cozy, 35h/week, $90k/y salary+benefits opportunity in
Germany.

But, I dreamed of what were then considered alien concepts: working from home,
freedom from commuting, and spending more quality time with my loved ones. I
wanted to break free, and become my own boss coming from a tightly managed
employment environment as an academic researcher.

Few people agreed with my view that freelancing would eventually become
mainstream, overtaking employment in population size because of its more
flexible and adaptable work model.

Yet, I didn't expect the snowballing speed with which the freelancing industry
would grow.

In the last seven years, we've seen a growth rate north of 15% per year.
Statistics show that there are already 1.5 billion (!) freelancers. And the
number of freelancers keeps growing relative to the 3.3 billion employed
people.

So, long story short, if you want to stay on the right side of change, the
data-driven decision would be to consider adding freelancing to your income
stream. Even if freelancing represents only an additional means to make money
that you can then reinvest to become an owner of scarce and desirable assets.

Freelancing is here to stay. What's the best way to start freelancing? Here's
a quick guide on the Finxter blog that's still relevant:

[[Blog] The Complete Guide to Freelance Developing]({Link})

Also, freelancing combines beautifully with exponential growth industries like
AI and Bitcoin. Here's an article that can help you stay ahead of the curve -
most coders haven't yet tried Langchain nor Auto-GPT:

[[Blog] Auto-GPT vs Langchain – What’s The Difference?]({Link})

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

PS: If you're not interested in our daily learning material, feel free to
unsubscribe by clicking [this link]({Link}). Although I'm sad to see people
go, I believe it's important to focus this email newsletter to motivated
coders and tech enthusiasts who want to continuously improve their skills on a
daily basis.

mischance in life was an opportunity to behave well. Every mischance in life
was an opportunity to learn something and your duty was not to be submerged in
self-pity, but to utilize the terrible blow in a constructive fashion. That is
a very good idea."_ — **2007 USC Law School**

_"You don’t have a lot of envy, you don’t have a lot of resentment, you don’t
overspend your income, you stay cheerful in spite of your troubles, you deal
with reliable people and you do what you’re supposed to do. All these simple
rules work so well to make your life better."_ — **2019 CNBC interview**

_"I think that a life properly lived is just learn, learn, learn all the
time."_ — **2017 Berkshire Hathaway Annual Meeting**

success in fishing. Fish where the fish are.’ You want to fish where the
bargains are. That simple. If the fishing is really lousy where you are you

14\. You Ain't Gonna Need It (YAGNI)  
15\. Don't Use Too Many Levels of Indentation  
16\. Use Metrics to Measure Code Quality  
17\. Boy Scout Rule and Refactoring

The article lesson above shows many examples. Check it out!

Be on the right side of change. 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'More Prompts Than Atoms in the Universe', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

Nobody fully understands why LLMs work.

The best analogy comes from Simon Willison, aka. [_LLM = alien
technology_]({Link}).

We don't know why a huge CSV file of numbers generates intelligent and useful
responses, so we don't know the limit of the model's usefulness and
intelligence.

Say you ask Midjourney to draw an image, but the result is garbage. You
conclude that the LLM is garbage.

Yet, somebody else may be able to produce a fantastic image using the same
model but with a slight variation of your prompt.

The model wasn't garbage after all - your prehistorian brain's ability to
communicate with _alien tech_ was!

One single word may completely change the output.

One word to go from garbage to world-class.

To prove this point, let's examine my daughter's most recent Midjourney
article:

👉 [ **Blog** ] [50 Best Midjourney Style Prompts (New Version 6)]({Link})

Here's how the character of the generated image changed by altering only one
word in a 32-word prompt (Midjourney's new version 6):

**REALISM:**

![](https://blog.finxter.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/12/Untitled-12.jpg)

**PICASSO:**

![](https://blog.finxter.com/wp-
content/uploads/2023/12/finxter.com_A_young_woman_with_straight_dark-
blonde_hair_and_mo_7ee65f72-5feb-497a-8d83-ce3b13f285d3-768x768.webp)

One word difference in a 30 word prompt!

Imagine what these models are already capable of - we haven't even scratched
the surface yet!

Even if we restricted our prompts to 100 words of English, there are

**30000 100**

valid prompt variations given that many highly effective prompts are just bag
of words.

It is estimated that there are only

**10 82**

atoms in the universe!

Tell that to the many non-believers arguing [prompt engineering]({Link}) is
BS.

Be on the right side of change. 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'We are still early', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})



Hey {User},

I bet you won't be surprised to hear the most frequently posed question from
Finxters worldwide:

_**Is coding dead?**  
(Read: Can I still make money with coding?)_

The answer is, of course, **_not at all_** _.  
(Read: Yes, you can make shitloads of money._

If coding were a human, it would be a toddler (1-3y) just entering early
childhood (3-6y). Four-year-old children have different abilities and
challenges than toddlers.

For instance, natural language becomes a more and more powerful tool in both
early childhood and coding today - using tools like Amazon Q (see yesterday's
article), GitHub Copilot, and just plain old ChatGPT.

🧑‍💻 **Tutorial:**[Amazon Q and CodeWhisperer in PyCharm - A Visual
Installation Guide with Examples]({Link})

To stretch the metaphor a bit, an early child can get 10x more done than a
toddler. Same for generative AI and AI-assisted coding.

You can talk to them, and they can reasonably interpret the deeper meaning of
your words!

Some will proclaim that coding is dead because they don't use the powerful
tools at their disposal.

Others will just use these tools to get 10x more done, make 10x more income,
and create 10x more value for society.

{'subject': '5 Top Bitcoin Articles in 2023', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

_"Chris - where should I start learning about X?"_

If I were a large language model, I'd have a lot of fine-tuning on this

explosive network effects and proliferating infrastructure helps us stay
relevant.

and Metcalfe's Law]({Link}).

agents will definitely adopt permissionless "Money-over-IP" technology!

The Internet -- Text-over-IP, Voice-over-IP, Netflix-over-IP -- was built on
top of the leading permissionless, decentralized TCP/IP protocol.

will be built on top of the leading permissionless, decentralized value-over-

{'subject': 'Meritocracy', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

Today, a long-term Finxter reader asked me for tips about hiring freelancers.

**_"How to find great freelancers?"_**

At Finxter, we're fortunate enough to have found a few [exceptional
freelancers]({Link}). How? I only really thought about it deeply after getting
asked this question.

Rather than trying to control everything, micro-manage, and allow subconscious
biases to reduce our decision quality, MBIT suggests letting freelancers self-
select over time based on merit rather than academic degrees, impressive CVs,
or other faulty proxies for job performance.

Check it out if you're interested in scaling your own online business. We all
need freelancers to help us out occasionally because we cannot do everything
ourselves.

Be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'Can you solve this puzzle?', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})



Hey {User},

fruits = ["Orange", "Strawberry", "Kiwi", "Pineapple", "Mango"]  
vitamin_c = [43.2, 58.8, 92.7, 47.8, 36.4]

max_vitamin_c = 0  
max_fruit = None  
max_index = None

for index, (fruit, vitamin_c) in enumerate(zip(fruits, vitamin_c)):  
    if vitamin_c > max_vitamin_c:  
        max_vitamin_c = vitamin_c  
        max_fruit = fruit  
        max_index = index

# Fruit with highest vitamin C with index  
print(max_index, max_fruit, max_vitamin_c)

{'subject': 'This article on Transformers gets a lot of attention', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

I realized that a recent Finxter article is getting a lot of attention (
_"Attention Is All You Need"_ 😅), so I thought I'll share it as today's
tutorial to help you stay ahead of the curve: 👇

[[Blog] Transformer vs LSTM: A Helpful Illustrated Guide]({Link})

**TLDR**? Both are artificial neural network architectures to capture the
essence of the training data.

**LSTM networks** are recurrent neural networks (RNNs) specifically designed
to address the vanishing gradient problem found in standard RNNs. They can
learn and retain long-range dependencies and are often used for sequence-to-
sequence (seq2seq) tasks, such as language translation or text generation.

**Transformers** have gained popularity with the rise of generative AI (e.g.,
ChatGPT) due to their parallelization capabilities and the introduction of the
attention mechanism, which allows them to effectively process large, complex
sequences without getting bogged down in sequential data processing.

More in the [blog]({Link})! 🧠

Let's stay on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'Why I Hold TSLA', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User}

Let's zoom ahead 3-5 years into the future.

The recession is over, ChatGPT has launched version GPT-8 (manages your health
better than your doctor), and Tesla has launched full self-driving (FSD) and
is about to launch the Optimus humanoid bot.

AI training costs persist in declining 70% per year and the promised
transformation into a new economy enabled by AI is in full force.

What does this mean for one of the world's AI leaders, Tesla?

I just completed a fun blog article on what I believe could be a possible per-
share valuation of the Tesla company assuming the humanoid bot story plays out
over a decade or so:

[[Blog Valuation] Tesla Bot Valuation: $15,625 per Share Possible?]({Link})

Here's the TLDR:

  * The Total Addressable Market (TAM) for functioning humanoid bots could reach $10 trillion per year, with billions of units deployed worldwide.
  * Tesla's strengths in battery technology, FSD, AI, large-scale production, and visionary leadership position it to capture a substantial share of the humanoid bot market.
  * If Tesla captures 25% of the market, this equates to roughly $2.5 trillion in annual profit due to the high software profit margins north of 50%. 
  * At a Price/Earnings (P/E) ratio of 20, conservative compared to some high-growth tech companies, this would give a market capitalization of $50 trillion.
  * With approximately 3.2 billion shares outstanding, this would equate to a share price of $15,625. Currently, it's at $280 so this would represent a 55x.

Crazy numbers, right?

Yes, this valuation represents just one potential path based on the success of
Tesla's humanoid bot program and the broader acceptance of humanoid bots in
society.

And you'd have to perform a probability-weighted expected value calculation.
However, I believe the fact that this scenario is not too unlikely should make
us stop and think.

To position ourselves on the right side of change, sometimes we need to
**become owners rather than stay busy workers** forever. I don't say you
should buy Tesla stock like me.

I'm not an investment advisor and you shouldn't consider this investment
advice obviously. ~~I'm just a random guy from the Internet after all.~~

But I'm convinced that many of the benefits of automation will accrue to the
owners of the few companies that'll win the AI race.

Ownership is important. Yet, statistically, only 20 to 25% of Finxters own
stocks. Three out of four Finxters won't benefit from the appreciation of the
stock market due to wild efficiency gains.

I want all Finxters to succeed - so if you're one of 75%, this may serve as a
slight nudge to consider.

To your success! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'The Art of Clean Code (7/10) - The Unix Philosophy', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

The Unix ecosystem is one of the most beautiful collective achievements in the
history of human collaboration.

In today's email, I've compiled the 15 most insightful Unix principles we can
use to become better coders, AI developers, or prompt engineers:

👉 [The Art of Clean Code – 15 Unix Principles]({Link})

  1. Make each program do one thing well
  2. Simple is better than complex
  3. Small is beautiful
  4. Build a prototype as soon as possible
  5. Choose portability over efficiency
  6. Store data in flat text files
  7. Use software leverage to your advantage
  8. Avoid captive user interfaces
  9. Make every program a filter
  10. Worse is better
  11. Clean code is better than clever code
  12. Design programs to be connected with other programs
  13. Make your code robust
  14. Repair what you can—but fail early and noisily
  15. Write programs to write programs

They are as relevant today as ever!

Be on the right side of change. 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'Ten Career Paths Post-GPT', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User}

Today I thought it'll be fun to dive into ten career paths that are likely to
work post AI, these are aggregated by Finxter **Emily**.

TLDR - Here's a short-form version of the article:

  * **AI Ethics Officer** : Ensures AI doesn't discriminate or harm, like preventing an AI system from rejecting job applications based on gender; $80,000 – $200,000. I bet this one will be massive based on today's "woke" society.
  * **AI Trainer** : Like a coach for AI, corrects its mistakes and teaches it to understand human speech or recognize images; $75,000 – $150,000. Autolabeling may be a threat though.
  * **Mental Health Professional** : Helps people through tough times, like a therapist listening to someone dealing with grief; $45,000 – $130,000. Mental health will be disrupted by AI eventually but most of it will be additional demand by "normal people" needing professional coaching and seeking personal development, IMO.
  * **Environmental Engineer** : Designs ways to install solar energy (booming!), clean oceans, or reduce pollution, such as creating sustainable waste management systems; $60,000 – $120,000.
  * **Special Education Teacher** : Tailors lessons for children with disabilities, such as using visual aids for a child with hearing impairment; $40,000 – $80,000.
  * **Healthcare Provider** : Takes care of patients, like a nurse assisting in surgery or a doctor using AI for early cancer detection; $80,000 – $300,000+.
  * **Social Worker** : Acts like a guiding friend, helping a struggling family find housing or a job; $40,000 – $80,000.
  * **Research Scientist** : Explores new frontiers, like discovering a new material that makes solar panels more efficient; $70,000 – $160,000.
  * **Creative Artist** : Paints, sculpts, or writes to express emotions or ideas, like an artist painting a mural that brings a community together; $20,000 – $100,000+.
  * **Human Resources Manager** : Like a matchmaker for companies and employees, finds the right people for the right jobs and helps them settle in; $65,000 – $200,000.

Personally, I'd add coding work that builds on and leverages LLM APIs and LLM-
based meta tools such as auto GPTs and simply prompt engineering, as well as
Bitcoin development on L2 (e.g., Lightning). Both are six-figure opportunities
for sure.

You can read the full blog guide with beautiful visuals here:

👉 [[Blog] Ten Sustainable Career Paths in the Post-AI Economy]({Link})

_Greetings from Hamburg, Germany. 🚢_

Let's stay on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'Worldcoin – Follow the Money', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User}

_"I’m really disappointed to see you so gleefully promote putting people out
of work. It’s not what I’m interested in using AI for."_

Lately, I've been receiving feedback by some Finxter readers similar to this.

I deserve it, too, because I continue to be highly excited about the upcoming
disruptions brought about by two significant forces: AI and Bitcoin.

**(1) Artificial intelligence**

LLMs like ChatGPT will put legions of knowledge workers out of work. The world
is awakening as we continue to put pretrained brains serialized into highly
compressed files in the form of LLMs into every imaginable object.

Intelligence is no longer a scarcity.

This is a transformational change as all things become aware and intelligent -
all products must be rethought. Opportunities to create value and ripe low-
hanging fruits by integrating LLMs into X are endless.

We are already on an exponential curve in AI training cost efficiency, the
number of robots deployed, and other metrics measuring rapid change.

Never underestimate the disruptive power of exponential change.

**(2) Bitcoin**

Bitcoin stands to mitigate the limitations introduced by large banking
institutions and corporate finance. It represents freedom money, retaining its
value while being transferred across distances and time.

Considering traditional finance systems like VISA levy a fee on every
transaction, traditional financial systems can be likened to sucking out our
life energy, if I may borrow Saylor's metaphor.

I think if you focus on these two technology disruptions, i.e., AI and
Bitcoin, you're well-equipped to stay on the right side of change.

Now, focusing is easier said than done, especially in our world of
distractions.

For instance, many Finxters these days send me questions on the following new
centralized technology startup.

👁️ [[Blog] Worldcoin – Who Pays for Universal Basic Income (UBI)?]({Link})

The premise of the project, cofounded by ChatGPT founder Sam Altman, is that
humanity will eventually need universal basic income to fairly distribute the
efficiency gains of "putting people out of work" (see the first sentence of
this email).

While I believe the idea of UBI is sound, I'm not a fan of the token or
centralized crypto projects like this one (no matter how often they use the
term "decentralization" to distract our focus.

But [read for yourself]({Link}) \- where does the money come from?

The future is bright - let's stay on the right side of change! 🌞  
Chris

PS: Welcome to our new [Finxter Premium Members]({Link})! Please give me a few
days to reply - I have been swamped with emails, but I'll eventually reply.

You can view my slow response time as "proof of humanity". 😅

{'subject': 'The Scarcest Resource on Earth', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User}

What is the scarcest desirable resource on Earth?

Before you read on, I want you to commit to an answer.

**Is human time the scarcest resource?**

No. You can always produce more humans. Your human time might be limited but
human time in general is a renewable resource.

**Is energy the scarcest resource?**

Well, no. Energy is infinite, and it is all around us. The sun is a giant
fusion reactor in the sky, and only a tiny portion of its emitted energy
arrives on Earth.

Think of the sun's energy as Niagara Falls, but trillions of times larger,
pouring out light instead of water. The tiny fraction that reaches Earth is
over 10,000 times our total energy use.

If harnessed effectively, it could power our world many times over.

**Is USD the scarcest resource?**

You are on the right track, but no. They wouldn't print it in the trillions if
fiat money were scarce. Look at any chart of the money supply growth (M1, M2,
M3) - they are all up to the right exponentially. 📈

Not how the supply of a scarce resource looks like.

**What about gold or diamonds?**

Gold is one of the scarcest resources on Earth. Yet it has an annual supply
growth of 2% per year. We mine more and more gold without an upper limit.

If the price of gold were to go ballistic (e.g., 10x), gold miners would
profitably mine much more gold. With increasing gold supply, the prices would
start to go down again.

The world economy is a self-regulating organism.

As for diamonds, despite their reputation for rarity, they are actually more
common than gold when you look deep within Earth. You can even synthetically
produce diamonds, so if the price rises, you'd mass-produce them, and the
price would drop again.

Neither gold nor diamonds are the scarcest resources on Earth.

**What about scarce and desirable real estate?**

Think of rare, prime real estate as the 'Picassos' of the property world. Like
original works of art from a master painter, there's a finite amount of this
prime property, especially in desirable areas like beachfronts or city
centers.

To illustrate, imagine the Manhattan skyline as a limited-edition collection
of sculptures. Once they're all taken, there's no more space for new ones -
the only way to get one is if someone decides to sell theirs. This is why
Manhattan real estate is among the most expensive globally; there's high
demand, but the supply is fundamentally limited.

In this sense, rare real estate can be as scarce as a precious gem.

Yet - there's always more land. Earth is big. There are 695,000 miles of
coastline, 29 times the Earth's circumference.

We could build more real estate in the desert, under the sea or floating on
it, on Mars, or just into the sky.

If you think about it, we'll even build more real estate in digital worlds as
more and more of our lives move into cyberspace. That's one of the reasons
Apple and Meta, two of the most profitable companies, focus on building
virtual reality devices.

**Is it intelligence?**

Not with the recent intelligence explosion we've been witnessing. During the
last few months, I've written extensively about LLM technology, AI, and
ChatGPT.

Our collective intelligence will go 1,000x over the next couple of decades.

**So what is the most scarce resource on Earth?**

The answer is ... Bitcoin!

Plain and simple.

Bitcoin is a monetary good with a fixed supply schedule. There will always
only be 21,000,000 BTC units. Each is infinitely divisible but there cannot be
more BTC without changing the protocol.

Unlike gold, diamonds, real estate, human time, intelligence, and any other
good on Earth, you cannot produce more of it when the price increases.

When more miners try to generate more BTC, the difficulty adjustment will make
it harder to produce it. This protects the cap of 21 million monetary units
from being hacked by higher energy expenditure and increasing human ingenuity.

It is desirable. You can use it as the official payment instrument in a
handful of countries already (like El Salvador).

There are an estimated 56 million millionaires in the world as of 2023. This
number is expected to grow to 87.5 million by 2026. Fiat inflation will
continue to produce more and more millionaires forever.

So not every USD millionaire can have a single Bitcoin, even though every USD
millionaire will want one to diversify and protect their net worth.

The only reason this scarce monetary protocol works is decentralization
(otherwise, it would become a fiat currency controlled by a single party).
That's also why the 20k+ other cryptos are inferior: they are less
decentralized.

Soon an infinite number of intelligent agents based on LLMs and other AI
technologies will start to acquire the scarcest good on Earth, which makes it
even more scarce for ordinary people like you and me.

US presidential candidates now propose to buy BTC to stabilize the US balance
sheets.

The biggest asset managers in the world -- Blackrock, Fidelity, BNY Mellon,
Vanguard -- have already started to accumulate BTC and will keep doing so.

The US will soon see a Bitcoin ETF, and a tsunami of new retail capital will
compete for the scarcest resource on Earth.

Nothing is inevitable, but objectively, Bitcoin is and is likely to remain the
scarcest resource on Earth.

To your success! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': "Here's to the misfits.", 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

_"Here's to the crazy ones. The misfits. The rebels. The troublemakers. The
round pegs in the square holes. The ones who see things differently."_ **\-
Steve Jobs**

I hate Instagram - it's all posing, testosterone, and the embodiment of the
shiny object syndrome. It's wasted time and life energy, so I've learned to
avoid it like the plague.

But here's something I love: _Midjourney_.

Even though it's often misused to create fake Instagram models of perfect
people and places.

They are all so perfect! 🦋🙄

**But what about the misfits?** What about boring everyday persons and
situations - workers shuffling dirt, people in the subway, everyday dishes
that don't get millions of views on Instagram with their perfect presentation?

Can we create those images with Midjourney, even though it (superficially)
seems to be trained with a bias toward perfect, beautiful people?

The answer is a resounding yes!

👇👇👇

{'subject': 'Python Entrepreneur Habits', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

I just designed this Python puzzle that also may give you some ideas on
powerful daily habits you can start implementing today to compound your
success. (Or you can just solve it for fun. 🧑‍💻)

🔗 [*** Solve Python Puzzle Online (Interactive) ***]({Link})

🐍🐍🐍

class Entrepreneur:  
def __init__(self):  
self.habits = {  
"learning": False, # Have you engaged in daily learning?  
"tasks": False, # Are your top 3 tasks for the day completed?  
"network": False, # Did you connect with someone in your network today?  
"mindful": True, # Are you practicing mindfulness or meditation?  
"exercise": True, # Did you engage in physical activity?  
"finance": False, # Was there a review of business finances today?  
"feedback": True, # Did you seek feedback on something?  
"focus": False, # Were there periods of focused, undistracted work?  
"skills": True, # Was time spent on skill development?  
"gratitude": True # Did you reflect on things they're grateful for?  
}

def __getitem__(self, habit):  
return self.habits.get(habit, False)

def __setitem__(self, habit, value):  
if habit in self.habits:  
self.habits[habit] = value

def day_summary(self):  
return sum(self.habits.values())

def toggle_habit(self, habit):  
self[habit] = not self[habit]

person = Entrepreneur()  
person.toggle_habit("learning")  
person.toggle_habit("mindful")  
person["tasks"] = True

print(person["learning"], person.day_summary())

🐍🐍🐍

**What's the output of this puzzle?**

Take your time to solve it and strengthen your Python skill. You can also have
an interactive and more readable puzzle version on the Finxter app and track
your Python skills here:

🔗 [*** Solve Python Puzzle Online (Interactive) ***]({Link})

Have fun - enjoy the start of the week.

Let's be on the right side of change - with the right habits! 🚀  
Chris

PS: Why did the habit go to school?

🤔

To become a routine **!**

{'subject': 'Alien Technology', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User}

Nobody fully understands how and why the magical technology LLM works.

The best mental model I've seen comes from Simon Willison, who calls LLMs
"Alien Technology" that was handed to us a couple of months ago, and we're
just starting to explore it. 👇

[[Blog] Alien Technology: Catching Up on LLMs, Prompting, ChatGPT Plugins &
Embeddings]({Link})

What we know is the following:

OpenAI, under the guidance of Sam Altman, recognized the immense potential in
the transformer architecture proposed in the 2017 paper _"Attention Is All You
Need"._

_Interestingly, this was a Google and Google Brain Research paper, but
Google's own researchers didn't understand the implications of their discovery
themselves._

In a Lex Friedman podcast, Sam Altman mentioned that the breakthrough happened
when they decided to boldly push the scale of computing and data farther than
anyone else.

We’re talking about millions of dollars spent on cutting-edge computing power
and terabytes of textual data to train these models. From what we know, the
training data seems to include massive amounts of pirated books and
copyrighted content such as the Harry Potter series - only that the LLM
obfuscates the copyright issues.

It’s a gargantuan effort that converges in a matrix of numbers — the model’s
parameters — that represent the learned patterns of human language.

By using an unprecedented amount of computing on an unprecedented amount of
data on a simple neural network architecture (transformers), intelligence
seems to be an emergent phenomenon.

I’d go as far as to say that the age-old process of reproducing human
intelligence has been transcended. Intelligence is solved. LLMs will only
become smarter from now on. Like the Internet, LLMs will stay and proliferate
and penetrate every single sector of our economy.

LLMs are densely compressed human wisdom, knowledge, and intelligence. Now
imagine having these files and being able to copy them millions of times,
running them all at once.

So picture this: Millions of intelligent student workers that are eager to
work day and night on anything you want. How would you use them?

In this email, I want to challenge you to think of novel use cases for
millions of intelligent workers working virtually for free. Because the only
limitation I see now and in the upcoming decades seems to be your imagination.

Let's stay on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

PS: I may be slow to respond to emails for the next few weeks as I'll be on a
road trip to Denmark with limited Wifi access. Don't worry if I skip a daily
email or two. I'll be back to my speedy self once I'm back online. Thanks for
understanding!

{'subject': 'Riding the Change Tsunami', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

This year has made it clear that disruption is just around the corner.

Every Finxter email ends with _"Be on the right side of change"_. Let's talk
about that - how to be on the right side?

Nobody knows for sure, but we can identify some behavioral patterns. For
simplicity, I categorized three personas and how they position themselves in
today's world:

(1) **Overt Deniers** 🥸 *minority*: _"Why would anyone ever need an automobile
when we have perfectly good horses?"_  
(2) **Passive Observers** 👀 *majority*: _"I read the Bitcoin whitepaper in
2015 and found it very interesting. But I found paying $300 per BTC too
expensive, so I didn't buy any."_  
(3) **Strategic Navigators** ⛵ *minority*: _"I watched an interview with Elon
Musk in 2013, believed in his ability to make things happen, and bought a
modest 1000 shares equivalent for $3/share. Today, this TSLA position alone is
worth $218,000._

Only group (3) anticipates change, acts accordingly, and benefits massively
from explosive, exponential disruptions.

Check out today's Finxter article on the topic:

[[Blog] Forecasting Isn’t Enough: The Art of Riding the Change
Tsunami]({Link})

[![](https://blog.finxter.com/wp-
content/uploads/2023/10/image-186.png)]({Link})

Thanks for being an avid Finxter reader. It keeps humbling me to see 150k
Finxters reading this daily email newsletter. ♥️

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'The Art of Clean Code (9/10) - Focus', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

Let's recap the eight core lessons and the unifying principle in _The Art of
Clean Code_ :

👉 [The Art of Clean Code – Focus as the Ultimate Weapon to Fight
Entropy]({Link})

If you take only one thing out of this 10-part tutorial series, it's that
focus is everything.

  * Unix lingo: _**Do One Thing Well**_
  * Bill Gates: _**Focus Is The Most Important Thing in Business**_
  * Elon Musk: _**Delete. Delete. Delete.**_

**TLDR** : Complexity leads to deadly Entropy. Productivity is reducing
Entropy. We reduce Entropy by using _focused effort_ :

  * Focus on the most productive 20% (80/20 Principle).
  * Build and iterate on minimal viable products (MVP).
  * Write concise code (17 Principles).
  * Avoid premature optimization (Six Types).
  * Foster a focused environment (Flow).
  * Simplify code with Unix's approach of doing one thing well.
  * Design with minimalism for clarity and effectiveness.

Check out the blog above for a quick rush through the most important concepts
addressed in the last eight lessons of the book!

Be on the right side of change. 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'LLM = Copyrighted Data Laundering?', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

Imagine your hacker friend Alice sends you three pirated coding ebooks.

For example, let's make it [Python One-Liners]({Link}), [The Art of Clean
Code]({Link}), and [The Book of Dash]({Link}). 😉🏴‍☠️

You're a law-abiding citizen so you decide to remove Alice's pirated ebooks
from your computer. But then a thought crosses your mind - before removing the
books from your device, you could read them first.

The books have been stored on your device anyway, so why not read them first
and only then remove them? The outcome is the same.

So you read the books, learn something new, and remove them from your device.

Your biological neural net has become more competent because it now
understands Python's ins and outs, the practicalities of creating successful
code projects, and how to create beautiful dashboard applications.

After deleting the copyrighted material from your computer, the only trace of
the pirated books is in the form of newly created synapses in your brain.

Your future output (e.g., speech or writing) may be partially based on the
copyrighted material.

But what actually comes out of your mouth is not a copyright violation only
because you've consumed copyrighted material. Your output is a mix of
everything you've ever consumed and, possibly, some of your own thoughts on
top.

That's roughly how ChatGPT and other LLMs did it: they learned from thousands
of copyrighted ebooks like Harry Potter without actually violating copyright
law. 👇

[[Blog] Top 10 LLM Training Datasets – It’s Money Laundering for Copyrighted
Data!]({Link})

Although I'm one of the authors whose material has been used without
compensation, it doesn't bother me. Between you and me, I'm super happy and
grateful that AI companies worldwide have had the guts to freely use the body
of human knowledge to train their giga brains and launch the LLM revolution.

Knowledge wants to be free.

Also, after yesterday's lesson 1, make sure to check out lesson 2 of our free
course on _OpenAI API Mastery - Function Calls and Embeddings_ : 👇

[[Blog] OpenAI API Functions & Embeddings Course (2/7): Function Calls with
Parameters]({Link})

Tomorrow, I'll remind you to finish this course (lesson 3) as this is crucial
knowledge in today's AI age. Stay tuned!

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'ChatGPT vs Human Coder ⚔️ Who Wins Fixing GitHub PRs', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

It's easy to fall into the belief that human roles, e.g., in software
engineering, are on the verge of being replaced.

I'm guilty of prematurely announcing various job roles dead, even though they
may survive another decade or so.

In defense of the more traditionalist argument that ChatGPT is overhyped, a
recent Princeton paper titled _“SWE-bench: Can Language Models Resolve Real-
World GitHub Issues?”_ sheds light on the limitations of even the most
advanced language models in the field of software development. 👇

[[Blog] Human Software Developers vs ChatGPT – Who’s Better in Fixing GitHub
Pull Requests?]({Link})

As you'll learn in the blog, human developers are still superior in 96% of
GitHub pull requests.

For now, we haven't seen LLMs replacing traditional software developer roles.
On the contrary, we have seen legions of new developer positions opening up in
[prompt engineering]({Link}), e.g., using the Python OpenAI API.

Like in chess, the arrival of strong AI has led to a revival of popularity and
interest in software engineering.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'Best Programming Language for Bitcoin', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

At Finxter, we want to anticipate and position ourselves to benefit from
change.

We all have seen the emergence of LLMs this year - while still underrated,
it's old news.

The capabilities of LLMs will continue to explode with AI training costs being
reduced by 70% per year, so in two years, we'll see 10x efficiency gains.

What does that imply?

Clearly, LLM-based AI agents (e.g., built with Python) will autonomously and
independently move through cyberspace and participate in the cyberspace
economy.

But in order to become autonomous economic agents, they need to be able to
send, receive, and hold money.

They cannot easily hold USD in a bank account because they are not human.

They cannot transact with VISA because they have no bank account and they
wouldn't be able to afford the ~2% tax on each transaction. If these bots used
VISA, only 35 transactions would halve their money!

That's why we can see projects like LangChainBitcoin that empower LLM-based
agents like Auto-GPT to participate in the economy via the Internet-native
monetary system: Bitcoin.

[[Blog] What is the Best Programming Language for Bitcoin?]({Link})

The tl;dr is that Python is the best programming language to develop apps and
bots on top of Bitcoin. Nobody really uses C++ to create apps these days.
However, if you want to become a protocol developer, you'd need to learn C++.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'Making Money with Python', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

About 90% of the readers of the Finxter newsletter are Python developers who
are interested in discussing financial matters. However, for some, this topic
is considered taboo despite the amount of time they dedicate to earning money.

Large Language Models (LLMs) like ChatGPT continue to automate large parts of
our economy.

To be on the right side of change, I believe, you must be an owner of scarce
and desirable assets so you'll benefit from automation.

You want to own, control, and leverage productive assets to your advantage.

There are two paths to asset ownership:

(1) Build the asset yourself (e.g., creating your own company), or

(2) Acquire the asset (e.g., purchasing ownership interest in disruptive
corporations like Facebook, Amazon, Tesla, Google, and Nvidia -- or buying a
stake in a scarce monetary network like Bitcoin).

In both cases, money is needed. So, let's make some money?

In this article, I give you a broad overview of how to make money with Python,
i.e., being in the automation industry where you are the disruptor rather than
you getting disrupted:

[[Blog] 55 Best Ideas to Make Money with Python]({Link})

Here are some example paths to make money with Python:

  * **Junior Web Developer** : Employed in tech startups, they build websites using Django or Flask, earning $40,000 - $60,000 annually.

  * **Machine Learning Engineer** : Working in tech or finance sectors, they design machine learning models, with salaries ranging from $80,000 - $150,000 yearly.

  * **Quant Developer in Finance** : Working in finance or banking, they design algorithms for trading or analysis, earning $100,000 - $240,000 yearly.
  * **Startup Founder** : Launching tech startups, their income is variable, potentially reaching $40,000+ monthly if successful.

There are many more career paths, some highly unconventional. [Read today's
Finxter article]({Link}) if you want to learn more and also consider joining
our best-selling [Finxter Freelancer Course]({Link}) for a detailed howto

Chris

{'subject': '4 Prompt Programming Skills', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

{'subject': 'Is ChatGPT greedy? I offered it a $1M tip', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})



Hey {User},

Are LLMs greedy?

Can you prompt engineer GPT-4 Turbo by offering it a tip on a perfect
response?

A Twitter user suggested that offering ChatGPT a $200 tip improves model
performance by 11% (even though it's impossible to _actually_ tip ChatGPT).

Unfortunately, I couldn't find any research on this topic: Academia is slow
and steady. I'm sure we'll see some papers in a couple of months.

But I couldn't wait, so I went ahead and conducted my own little study,
Guerilla-style using only $7 OpenAI credits and a few hours of my time:

[[Original Research] Are LLMs Greedy? An Experimental Analysis of the Tipping
Prompt ($0 to $1 Million)]({Link})

The initial experiments on a coding-related prompt show that tipping may offer
some benefits, although the tipping amounts seem crucial.

For example, if the offered tip is tiny (e.g., $0.1), GPT-4 Turbo will perform
_worse_.

~~(My scientific explanation: The model feels insulted.)~~

In our example, the quality "improvements" from using this prompting technique
range from -27% to +57% when offering a tip of $0.1 and $1,000,000,
respectively.

However, this is not published research and my research skills have become a
bit rusty over the last 3-4 years. Further research using different types of
prompts with ground truth is definitely needed to validate this hypothesis.*

Feel free to check out the article and share it with your friends and
colleagues if you find it worthy of sharing.

If you have additional prompt ideas that allow us to measure quality easily
and objectively, feel free to let me know.

Be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris



_*Shoutout to the few thousand academic researchers and computer science
professors reading the Finxter newsletter._

{'subject': 'Everybody Underestimates This Dirty Little Skill', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

Using an LLM is only half of the equation of sound prompt engineering. The
other half is passing high-quality context data into the prompts.

For example, you can use tools such as [LlamaIndex]({Link}) to load external
data into LLMs.

_But how do you get this data in the first place?_

The answer remains as dirty as ever: **web scraping**.

That's why web scraping, the skill, is in high demand. In fact, Google Trends
shows that interest in web scraping is at an all-time high after growing in
popularity every year since 2004!

Today's article shows how Finxter Charles used his web scraping skills to
create a high-quality data set that can be used as the basis of a high-quality
LLM pipeline: 👇

[[Blog] How I Scraped Data From Over 16,000 Gyms from MindBodyOnline]({Link})

The next step would be to pass that data into a web app using [OpenAI's
Embeddings API]({Link}). This is the technical blueprint of many of the new
startups that are popping up everywhere:

_Web scraping 👉 "Proprietary" data set 👉 OpenAI Embeddings API 👉 Real-world
utility_

You can apply this blueprint to almost every industry - keep it simple!

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'Starling-7B: New Open-Source LLM', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

Elon's vision when cofounding OpenAI was to create an open-source non-profit
counterweight to big tech AI.

Arguably, they have succeeded in scaling intelligence with LLM alien
technology. However, many of us believe that OpenAI has failed to deliver
open-source AI that is freely accessible by anybody.

Well - technological disruption works in magical ways.

While OpenAI's large language models are indeed closed-source, the performance
of competing open-source models -- like Llama 2 and Claude 2 -- is growing
even faster than OpenAI's.

So, indirectly and accidentally, OpenAI succeeded in providing us with open-
source AI systems that are highly performant, downloadable, and freely
accessible by anybody.

In today's Finxter article, let's review one of those open-source models that

{'subject': 'Top 7 GPTs Created by Finxters', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})



Hey {User},

Yesterday, I asked the community to share their own GPT creations, and I was
happy to receive many submissions! 👇

[![]({Link})]({Link})

[[Blog] Top 7 GPTs Created by Finxters]({Link})

These are the seven GPTs:

  * **Abominable Snowman** : Created by Matt in Denver, this GPT provides snow conditions and recommendations for ski resorts
  * **Giggles Grim** : Developed by Marcel, it's a pessimistic AI that cynically interprets current news
  * **Floyd Corner** : Bernard's creation, an AI-powered insurance expert that answers specific policy-related questions
  * **Recovery Counselor** : A beta-version GPT by Emir, designed to support addiction recovery with expert advice and inspirational quotes
  * **AI Finxter** : A GPT focusing on Python, AI, and technology, contributed by Gabor, a Finxter author
  * **Dad Jokes** : Jason's creation, a family-friendly comedian GPT that tells clean dad jokes, ideal for family entertainment
  * **Grill Genius** : Another of Jason's projects, this GPT offers assistance with BBQ recipes, grill temperatures, tips, and tricks

When I showed some of them to my wife, she asked a good question: why not use
the normal ChatGPT?

Any GPT Creator has to be able to answer that question, or its creation will
fail.

Three big general advantages of GPTs are that they can act more like Auto-GPT
going through a multi-prompt process, access third-party APIs using "Actions",
and focus on usability, branding, and extensive testing.

GPT developers must extensively test the GPT to help users go through a big or
small (but well-defined) user journey or transformation.

Not all these boxes are checked by all of the seven Finxter GPTs, but trying
as many as possible is worthwhile. As Jeff Bezos kept writing in his
shareholder letters:

_This is still day 1 for the Internet!_

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris
