{'subject': 'Mass Unemployment 2.0', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

Two days ago, I shared this blog article with you and other Finxters:

🧑‍💻 [[Blog] The Return of Mass Unemployment – Intelligent AI Bots, Expensive
Capital, and Recession]({Link})

In the email, I wrote:

**_"As a business owner, I'd rather hire one skilled prompt engineer than ten
graphic designers."_**

I already expected to get some pushback here - and I did!

For example, an anonymous Finxter wrote the following:

~~~

_Not just "no". HELL no!_

_I would not do business with you or anyone who would do that to people.
[...]_

_You do realize developers will be replaced the same way if we proceed down
this route?_

_What are all these displaced people going to do. Such tools need to be shut
down until this issue is figured out,_

_I am unsubscribing from your mailing list. I can’t support such unethical
behavior._

~~~

I understand that many feel threatened by the rapid technological acceleration
and the changes that come with it.

That's why I write this daily newsletter to help you stay on the right side of
change.

And, of course, anybody not feeling in alignment with our overall optimistic
attitude toward technological developments should, in fact, unsubscribe from
this email list immediately. No hard feelings.

Now let me make my case:

Our time on earth is limited. Many of us don't enjoy meaningless work that
could be automated. It's frustrating!

And why bother? We all know that meaningful work exists that doesn't get done.

So, my general attitude towards automation is as follows:

**_Every valuable task that can be automated, should be automated._**

Politics aside, here are two observations:

(1) Many **_people don't want to_** do the work, and  
(2) More and more **_machines can do_** the work cheaply, efficiently, and
without complaining.

For example, ChatGPT does an excellent job finding examples of how tech
advancements impacted certain job roles:

  * _**Scribes and Illuminators (Post-Printing Press):** Before the printing press, books were written by hand, often by monks in monasteries. The printing press made mass production of books possible, drastically reducing the need for manual scribes and illuminators who decorated manuscripts._

  * _**Weavers and Textile Artisans (Industrial Revolution):** The invention of mechanized looms and other textile machinery during the Industrial Revolution significantly reduced the demand for handweaving, impacting artisans who had traditionally woven textiles by hand._

  * _**Blacksmiths (Advent of Automobiles):** The widespread adoption of cars led to a decline in horse-drawn carriages, which adversely affected blacksmiths who were essential in making and repairing horse-drawn carriage components and horseshoes._

  * _**Lamplighters (Electric Lighting):** Before electric streetlights, lamplighters were employed to light gas or oil street lamps every evening. The advent of electric lighting rendered this occupation obsolete._

  * _**Telegraph Operators (Telephone and Internet):** With the advent of the telephone and later the internet, the need for telegraph operators, who transmitted messages using Morse code, diminished significantly._

  * _**Typesetters (Digital Printing and Publishing):** The rise of digital printing technologies and desktop publishing software reduced the need for manual typesetters, who arranged letters for printing presses._

  * _**Film Photographers and Darkroom Technicians (Digital Photography):** The digital photography revolution led to a decline in demand for traditional film-based photographers and darkroom technicians who developed film._

  * _**Travel Agents (Online Booking Platforms):** The rise of online travel booking platforms has significantly reduced the need for traditional travel agents, as people can now plan and book trips themselves online._

  * _**Bank Tellers (Online Banking and ATMs):** The introduction of ATMs and online banking services has decreased the need for as many bank tellers, as customers can perform many banking tasks themselves without visiting a branch._

  * _**Video Store Clerks (Streaming Services):** The rise of online streaming services like Netflix and Hulu has dramatically reduced the demand for video rental stores, impacting the jobs of video store clerks._

I didn't hire a secretary to make this but paid $20/m to an AI company. Making
this list would've taken me an hour or two - now it's just a few seconds.

If you're on the right side of change, you'll get attacked for using electric
vehicles that drive themselves (no Uber driver!), streaming videos (no video
stores!), or purchasing online (no department stores!).

**_"I can't support such unethical behavior."_**

In the end, of course, it doesn't matter.

_"No force on earth can stop an idea whose time has come."_ \- **Victor Hugo**

So why bother? There is no moral high ground for not using technology.

In fact, if we don't adopt new technologies, we'll die!

Adapt or die.

Be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

Q: Why did the programmer quit his job?

**def** job(quit= **False** ):  
**try** :

**finally** :  
**if** quit:  
**return** 'quit'

print(job(quit=True))

{'subject': 'Is ChatGPT creative?', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

Opinions are cheap. Everybody has one. And everybody loves sharing them.

Is ChatGPT creative?

I wasn't particularly eager to plow through seas of "Yes because" and "No
because" opinion pieces, but I wanted to read actual research papers that
objectively quantify this question.

avenue.

compilation of these three papers:

[[Blog] Is ChatGPT Creative?]({Link})

If you're interested in creative work and using ChatGPT to boost your creative
output, this may be a valuable read for you.

Let's stay on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': "30 Tasks AI Can't Replace (Yet)", 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

Large language models have scaled up intelligence.

But many activities still require a human touch.

These tasks, often perceived as _**dull daily routines**_ , hold significant
value precisely because they are not yet easy to automate.

A prime example of such tasks is the act of showing affection, like hugging
your children or caring for your parents and family. Kindness towards others
who seek your attention is another.

If somebody sends you an email with a question, it's a nudge from the world
that you're not yet fully replaceable by ChatGPT.

In today's blog, I've compiled a list of "trivial" things we're still needed
for - and that are not rocket science (for us):

🧑‍💻 [ **Blog** ] [30 Everyday Human Tasks AI Can’t Replace in the Foreseeable
Future]({Link})

Activities like holding and controlling investments, buying or renovating a
house also fall into this category.

We need to apply for the loan, orchestrate human labor, find sellers and
buyers, and prompt ChatGPT to spit out real estate copy.

They are not just technical transactions but involve a series of decisions and
interactions that are deeply human.

One day, these tasks may be automated. But today, the Universe still wants us
to do them.

To be on the right side of change, we need to appreciate the little things and
be grateful for every opportunity to participate in value creation.

That's why I appreciate every single email from a Finxter community member -
even though I often need some time to reply, it's great to talk to other human
beings amidst all the disruption.

Be on the right side of change. 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': '0.3 million satoshis for you?', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

  
Hey {User},

Finxter reader Maria expressed her interest in a Bitcoin Lightning course
specifically for coders as a future [academy]({Link}) course in the future.

I wanted to probe the community's interest in the Bitcoin protocol first, so I
came up with a fun giveaway:

We'll give away $100 in Bitcoin (341,000 Sats) in the [Finxter Discord
Mastermind Group]({Link}) within 24 hours.

How exactly does it work?

I'll post a Python puzzle revealing the public/private Bitcoin key of a wallet
with $100 in Bitcoin into the **#👑-mastermind** channel.

The public key will be the wallet's address. The private key will be the
password that unlocks the contents of the wallets.

So to get the Sats you would have to "steal" the funds with the leaked private
key using any standard wallet software of your choice.

The first one to transfer "my" BTC with the leaked private key to their
account gets it. Ready? Set. Go!

If you're already a premium member, keep checking the group. If you're not a
premium member, feel free to [join us]({Link}).

I'll post my private key between now and Friday, 12th of August, 18:28 UTC.

Let's stay on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

PS: There's a vital takeaway here: NEVER store your private keys in the cloud
or your computer. Keep them private. Not your keys, not your coins. If your
keys are public, you don't own them.

A million people or so lost some of their Bitcoin in the last 12 months
because they didn't own their private keys and the entity owning their private
keys defrauded them or lost the funds.

{'subject': 'When Bureaucracy Eats Tech', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

She was pissed off.

I chatted with a medical doctor today, and she was frustrated, not with the
usual hustle and bustle in the university clinic but with the health system
itself.

The reason she's annoyed is not the patient work - overwhelming as it is.

Like many doctors, she loves healing humans and wants to do more of it.

But the world is not that simple!

Instead of saving lives by leveraging her high-value skills, 12 years in the
making, she spends half of her time with repetitive and unnecessary
administrative work that an entry-level Python coder or prompt engineer could
easily automate.

For example, she was told to create a handwritten (!) letter for a patient
today because she couldn't print it (OPSEC).

In an age where we can communicate instantly across the globe, she had to
handwrite a letter for a patient because of some outdated rule. It's like
having a Ferrari but being told you can only drive it in first gear.

And it's us, collectively, who pays for the under-utilized Ferrari in the
first place.

A good friend (medical doctor) spends 30% of his time filling out forms
because the head of his clinic doesn't want to hire an entry-level developer
to create a simple data-entry app that could instantly free up half of the
time from 50 doctors working in that clinic alone.

With the rise of AI, the technological solutions for many real-world problems
are already out there. They need you, a curious tech enthusiast who plugs the
right tech solution into the real-world system.

Not rocket science, just making the world a better place.

Leveraging AI isn't just about science and technology; it's mostly about
driving tangible business results.

Companies and organizations seek developers like you who can help them
integrate existing technology into their systems.

Skilled AI consultants are needed in every organization today, whether they
know it or not.

By mastering AI, you can offer invaluable services, differentiate your
business, and tap into lucrative opportunities.

For the technical skills needed, I've created a conceptual learning path you
can follow:

[[10-Step Learning Path] Python Beginner to Advanced AI Coder]({Link}) _⭐ New
⭐_

The TLDR:

  1. **Foundations of Programming** : Begin with Python, the go-to language for AI and machine learning.
  2. **Data Structures & Algorithms**: Grasp the essentials of computational logic and data manipulation.
  3. **Object-Oriented Programming** : Dive deeper into software design and advanced programming concepts.
  4. **Introduction to Language Models** : Understand the basics of models like GPT and their applications.
  5. **Web Data Extraction** : Learn to gather and process data, a foundational skill for training and utilizing LLMs.
  6. **Natural Language Processing** : Explore text analysis, crucial for maximizing the potential of ChatGPT and other LLMs.
  7. **Deep Dive into ChatGPT** : Understand its architecture, capabilities, and practical applications in business.
  8. **Advanced LLM Concepts** : Delve into the intricacies of large language models, their training, and real-world applications.

Check out the [blog post]({Link}) for the 10-step learning path with our
training courses on the Finxter Academy.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': '3 Ways to Make Money with ChatGPT', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})



Hey {User},

There are many routes to making money with ChatGPT as a prompt engineer.

🔗 **Blog** : [3 Ways to Make Money with ChatGPT - The Good, The Bad, and The
Ugly]({Link})

Let's examine three, from worse to better! 👇

**Route #1 - Create Massive Amounts of Garbage Content**

The obvious way is to use it to create massive amounts of content.

As a [Python prompt engineer]({Link}), you can create a pipeline that crawls
webpages, passes them as embeddings into [GPT-4 Turbo]({Link}) with its huge
context window of 128k tokens, and ask it to create articles based on the
input and its own knowledge.

Then monetize these articles with ads.

However, I don't think this is the best way - it's very crowded!

And why bother? It adds little value to the world.

Because everybody is doing it, most won't make money this way.

So let's move on:

**Route #2 - Create Quality Content**

A much better route.

You can use AI to do research and help you obtain, analyze, and visualize
data.

Code interpreter and [GPTs]({Link}) can help you enrich your content. Use
ChatGPT to fix grammar mistakes and improve clarity.

The Internet is a winner-takes-most market. In other words, increasing your
content quality just a tiny bit can double your reach.

Want to double your reach again? Increase the quality of your content even
more!

Mister Beast teaches us that it never ends.

Due to the winner-takes-most dynamics, investing human time in content quality
pays off in the long term.

The opposite is also true: you should definitely use AI to enrich your content
with unique insights or tools.

For instance, a human chess player guiding a chess AI will beat both, an
expert chess player without AI, and a chess AI without guiding humans.

For that reason, AI-enriched human content is a sustainable route to leverage
AI to make money and have a real positive impact.

**Route #3 - Sell Your Consulting Services**

Still - both routes #1 and #2 are very crowded and it takes years of daily
effort just to get the foot in the door.

You need to love the game, or you won't make it through the years of unpaid
work. The content creation market is brutal and if you see small success,
you'll get copied very quickly.

Moreover, content creation doesn't pay off quickly - successful content
creators give it their all for many years before reaching good income levels.

It's not easy. You must become an expert.

An easier route in my opinion -- higher _expected value_ and a priori _success
probability_ \-- is to help businesses integrate [alien technology]({Link})
into their existing business systems.

The LLM paradigm shift has not yet trickled into the "normal" world. Millions
of businesses still need to integrate generative AI in their workflows.

We are in year #1 of publicly available LLM [APIs]({Link}).

Even without considering likely improvements of the foundational models, it'll
take years to connect and integrate LLMs with real world business systems.

**Who Pays for AI Consultants?**

Architects, financial advisors, grocery stores, software companies,
restaurants, clothing stores, laundromats, bookstores, fitness centers,
daycare centers -- all of them can and eventually will improve efficiency,
i.e., maximize benefit/cost ratio, by integrating LLMs into their workflows.

As an exercise to train your business savvy, feel free to take a minute to
come up with little ways to use generative AI and LLMs to improve each of
these businesses!

Think small.

Some minor examples:

  * If you run a hair salon, can you delight your customers by using the [Midjourney]({Link}) **_/merge_** command to experiment with personalized hair pictures of your customers?
  * If you run a small factory, can you use [OpenAI's text-to-speech (TTS) library]({Link}) to welcome customers at the front door?
  * If you are a financial advisor, can you delight your clients by using LLMs to [enrich portfolio analysis]({Link}) or visualize your clients' portfolios?
  * As a solar company, can you fully automate offer creation by means of a [fine-tuned]({Link}) LLM?

[AI consultants on Upwork]({Link}) make $100 per hour and more. Why? Because
of the huge leverage they offer to normal businesses that just don't know how
to do these things.

If you are such a business owner, hiring an AI consultancy for three hours
could increase your customer satisfaction and revenue by 10%, 20%, or even
100%!

_Who wouldn 't spend a few hundred bucks on that bet?_

Moreover, to reduce perceived risk and boost revenue, creative AI consultants
can propose revenue-share models where local businesses don't need to pay
upfront - but only an agreed-upon percentage of increased revenue after
success.

In that case, the average hourly rate could be much higher, as the AI
consultants would get a stake in the businesses.

Consider what I wrote a couple of emails ago:

_" I'd rather hire one skilled prompt engineer than ten graphic designers"_

The same would apply to 50/50 partnerships.

This opportunity is massive for anybody who wants to be on the right side of
change. Collectively, there's orders of magnitude more revenue in serving
businesses than in content creation.

Scalability and passivity can be obtained through creative partnerships.

For example, boosting revenue by 20% of a business making $50k/m can increase
business value by $100k to $500k. Many small businesses in your local
environment have these revenue levels.

And who knows, there may be a possibility to scale up the consultancy to a
more [scalable Saas business]({Link}) to take it to the next level?

Be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'Injecting Life Energy Into LLMs', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

Peter Thiel, who was the first outside investor to foresee the potential of
Facebook, and who also co-founded PayPal and Palantir, delivered the keynote
speech at last year's Bitcoin conference.

During his speech, he named Bitcoin as the best contender to eventually rival
the size of the equities market, predicting that it could increase in value by
100 times from the then-current price of roughly $43,000.

Today's price is $27,000, and many positive developments and [network
effects]({Link}) have been built since then.

Here's one narrative that I believe will take over mainstream media in the
years to come:

**BTC is permissionless, Internet-native money for billions of autonomous
agents** awakening in cyberspace. It becomes increasingly apparent that this
new economy will be built on Bitcoin Lightning rails, i.e., _"permissionless
money over IP"_.

  * AI agents don't have access to VISA cards, nor will they pay 2% transaction fees to VISA because sending money 35x back and forth would result in a 50% monetary loss to VISA!
  * AI agents cannot create bank accounts. But they will participate in the global economy eventually. So the question is: how?
  * AI agents cannot afford to lose half their purchasing power in just 35x transactions.

They _need_ permissionless money over IP.

The technically superior solution with the highest uptime and the solution
with the strongest network effects right now is _Bitcoin Lightning_ for micro
transactions due to its decentralized, open-source, permissionless access, as
well as its 24/7*365 availability, and immediate final settlement properties.

As a coder, if you want to learn how to create LLMs with access to money over
IP, feel free to check out today's Finxter article:

[[Blog] Injecting Life Energy Into AIs with Bitcoin, LLMs, APIs, & Lightning
⚡🤖]({Link})

Also, if you'd love to recap the philosophical foundations of the emerging
crypto industry, check out [this]({Link}) interesting talk given a couple of
days ago by Bitcoin OG Erik Voorhees on YouTube.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'The Art of Clean Code (5/10) - Premature Optimization', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

There is no Nobel Prize in computer science.

But we have something similar: _**The Turing Award**_. It's the highest
distinction in computer science -- and it carries a $1M price financially
supported by a well-known search giant that funds the web: Google.

A famous recipient of the Turing Award is Donald Knuth for his contributions
_"to the analysis of algorithms and the design of programming languages, and
in particular for his contributions to the "art of computer programming"
through his well-known books in a continuous series by this title."_

Today's lesson follows a Turing-Award-winning idea addressed in our _The Art
of Clean Code_ chapter titled:

👉 [Premature Optimization Is The Root of All Evil]({Link})

Optimizing parts of a system too early can lead to unnecessary complexity and
hinder overall progress. It is better to make the system work correctly and
then optimize only if necessary and where it makes the most impact.

For instance, don't spend a lot of time optimizing code that is rarely used (
_use profiling tools!_ ), don't add too many features to your product ( _MVP!_
), and don't worry about scaling your startup to millions of customers if you
haven't served hundreds yet.

Check out today's article lesson for more!

Be on the right side of change. 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'Garbage-In Garbage-Out', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

With the rising interest in generative AI, all of us are seeking signal in a
noisy world.

Those passionate about AI understand that a model's effectiveness is only as
good as its input training data. The principle of "Garbage in, Garbage out"
applies here.

If you regularly consume superficial news with a negativity bias, it's easy to
predict how your brain might respond to new information: with rejection,
doubt, and criticism, often stemming from impulsive thinking.

I receive statements like these: _"... I read that AI already becomes dumber,
and it only averages all available information without producing anything new
or creative ..."_

If you point people to research indicating that ChatGPT ranks higher on
creativity tests, they argue that the tests must be faulty. Yeah, sure they
are faulty. Still, it's better to go with Occam's Razor, embrace the simple
explanation, and remain open-minded in the face of change.

It may sound amusing, but many people dismiss the idea that [Large Language
Models (LLMs)]({Link}) are a disruptive force, set to multiply their impact
tenfold every two years, thanks to the exponential decline of AI training
costs.

The contrary to "Garbage-In Garbage-Out" also holds: if you train a model (or
your brain for that matter) on high-quality data, you're much more likely to
produce high-quality outputs.

_Quality-In Quality-Out_

So how can you cleanse your training data and, thereby, boost the performance
of the AI model that is your brain?

Here are some strategies I employ:

  * **Go for long walks.** After a walk in nature, I always find clarity about my next step. Taking one step at a time, with a distant long-term goal in mind, simplifies life. Clarity becomes increasingly vital as the influx of low-quality information leads to confusion, brain fog, and fatigue.
  * **Think slowly and take time.** Many people form shallow and hasty conclusions, presenting them with undue confidence. I've learned that such quick opinions, though easy to offer, often hold little value.
  * **Listen to podcasts with field experts** but only on topics within their expertise; I avoid those who speak outside their domain. Don't necessarily listen on Bitcoiner's advice on food or the money tips from broke people (you may be able to leverage the powerful technique of inversion though: _do the opposite_ ).
  * **Occasionally browse Twitter** /X – but not too often, as it can be a time sink. Among the noise, you might find a valuable insight, but I'm cautious with social media. Better yet - avoid all social media including X.
  * **Read select tech and coding newsletters**. I strive to offer such a newsletter with a high signal-to-noise ratio – you be the judge.
  * **Skim ArXiv** and new research papers: these are often a rich source of knowledge and remain some of the highest-quality information available.
  * **HackerNews** is also an excellent source for straightforward news with a high signal-to-noise ratio.

This brings us to today's Finxter tutorial if you're interested in building
your own HackerNews-like site:

[[Blog] How I Coded a Hacker News Clone in Django]({Link})

Enjoy reading! Windy greetings from Denmark!

Let's stay on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'Free LLM coder course inside (7 easy lessons)', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

I'd rather be roughly right than precisely wrong. Let's do some rough napkin
math:

  * With ~30 million coders worldwide, about 0.4% of humans can code.
  * ~80% of coders have tried LLMs like ChatGPT.
  * Of those, only 10% have tried the Python OpenAI API.
  * And only 5% of those have used OpenAI API functions and embeddings.

Putting these numbers together, only _**0.4% * 80% * 10% * 5% = 0.0016%**_
understand _OpenAI API functions and embeddings_. And this number is likely
way too optimistic.

In other words, less than **_one in 60,000_** currently has the skills to
leverage OpenAI API functions or embeddings -- when almost every business
could use _multiple_ coders with those skills.

Yet, many coders have convinced themselves that they can't join the top 1% in
their fields when staying ahead of the curve may simply require some basic
curiosity.

_You could learn OpenAI function calls and embeddings in a day or two..._

{'subject': 'Live Longer Healthily ... with Google?', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User}

In yesterday's email I asked whether you'd be interested in exploring Google's
fascinating Med-PaLM 2 research.

I was delighted to receive not just one or two, but more than a dozen
affirmative responses!

Your enthusiasm inspired me to dive deeper into the topic today. Here's the
result of my day's work: 👇

[[Blog] Med-PaLM 2: Will This Google Research Help You Increase Your
Healthspan?]({Link})

If you've been enjoying these daily email updates on cutting-edge research on
AI and LLMs, I'd like to ask you for a small favor: Could you kindly consider
inviting your friends or colleagues to [join this free email

{'subject': "xAI Grok - Elon's Reply to OpenAI", 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

After all the drama between OpenAI and Elon Musk -- Elon having contributed
millions to create the "non-profit" OpenAI that then turned for profit against
Elon's recommendations -- Elon has launched xAI.

xAI has already gathered some first-class AI researchers, and it's not to be
underestimated. Now they have released Grok, a humorous large language model
that not only gives answers à la Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy but also
proposes the right questions. 😉

[[Blog] Elon Musk's xAI Releases a New Humorous LLM Called Grok Based on
Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy]({Link})

Although Grok hasn't yet reached GPT-4's performance, it has already surpassed
GPT-3.5 in many benchmarks so it's a force to be reckoned with.

**Why the term _Grok_?**

Grok is a term coined by science fiction writer Robert A. Heinlein from the
novel "Stranger in a Strange Land" about a human raised on Mars. From the
book:

_Grok means "to understand", of course, but Dr. Mahmoud, who might be termed
the leading Terran expert on Martians, explains that it also means, "to drink"
and "a hundred other English words, words which we think of as antithetical
concepts. 'Grok' means all of these. It means 'fear', it means 'love', it
means 'hate' – proper hate, for by the Martian 'map' you cannot hate anything
unless you grok it, understand it so thoroughly that you merge with it and it
merges with you – then you can hate it. By hating yourself. But this implies
that you love it, too, and cherish it and would not have it otherwise. Then
you can hate – and (I think) Martian hate is an emotion so black that the
nearest human equivalent could only be called mild distaste._

Whatever the term means exactly, it won't be the last time you hear it; so
much we can be sure of!

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': "Let's talk about habits", 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

Here's something you already know:

_**Consistent habits over time compound to explosive success.**_

But although we already know how powerful and life-changing habits can be, we
often underestimate their results. That's in the nature of compounding and
exponentials.

As a result, we often don't take them as seriously as we should in the daily
whirlwind.

Today's email should be nothing else than a short reminder to set up a habit
tracker (e.g., Google Sheet with a simple YES/NO checker) and a habit that you
know can change your life if done over a long period of time.

For example, let me suggest one habit I'm highly confident can make you rich
in the next 10 years - that will help you stay on the right side of change:

One example habit would be _**spending one hour daily creating GPTs for the
GPT Store**_.

In five years, the GPT Store will be much bigger than it is now - it's a high-
growth industry.

Mobile app developers who have created simple apps on a daily basis since the
launch of the Android App Store or Apple App Store have achieved significant
success.

Say you do this for one, two, or three years: spending one hour every day to
launch a GPT into the store daily.

Launching 1000 GPTs during the next 1000 days, roughly three years, will
almost guarantee explosive success. The top 10 out of 1000 GPTs are likely to
create value for millions of people.

Your top GPT among 1000 may reach tens of millions of people.

But the remaining 990 are still valuable because they make the few winners
possible. We need the 990 to get the 10.

Habits compound.

And even if the GPT Store is not as successful, which I don't believe, you
will still learn a lot of new things and stay on top of developments in a
rapidly growing field.

A simple example of a powerful daily keystone habit. Of course, it's only one
idea of many that will work.

Now, the action step: what's your daily habit to compound your knowledge,
experience, and success in an explosive way over a long period of time?

Be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'Transformers Crush Meteorology 10,000:1', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})



Hey {User},

Did you check the weather today?

🌞 **ChatGPT** : _" On December 15, 2023, New York City is expected to
experience a mild and dry day with highs around 50°F and lows near 36°F."_

Simulation is how the magical prediction accuracy happens.

I have a lot of respect for simulation engineers. The few I know are skilled
coders, reliable data scientists, Linux experts, and math wizards.

While many German simulation engineers work simulate things like noise impacts
of rearview mirror designs in automotive, some of the best simulation experts
forecast the weather.

If you're curious about how weather simulation works, here's a glimpse into
what runs twice a day on a dedicated High Performance Cluster:

_" A weather model divides the world or a region into small grid cells. Each
cell is about 4 km to 40 km wide and 100 m to 2 km high. Our models contain 60
vertical atmospheric layers and reach deep into the stratosphere up to 60 km,
which corresponds to pressure of 10-25 hPa. The weather is simulated by
solving complex mathematical equations between all grid cells every few
seconds. The computed values of weather variables, such as temperature, wind
speed or cloudiness are stored every hour."_

Sounds complex, doesn't it? It's also a lot of computational work!

Couldn't we just throw AI at the problem, i.e., training the model once and
using inference twice a day to predict the weather?

_**Training may be expensive, but inference is very cheap.**_

Yes, we can.

In a groundbreaking new Nature paper, a group of Huawei researchers show how
it's done:

🌧️ **[Article]** [AI Weather Model BEATS Meteorologists - Higher Accuracy But
10,000x Faster!]({Link})

Not only was this the first time a Chinese tech company has managed to publish
a paper in _Nature_ without external coauthors, but it was also the first time
an AI-based model had beaten the state-of-the-art, world's best weather
simulation benchmark!

When visiting computer science conferences ten years ago, my colleagues and I
observed that machine learning was about to eat every discipline in computer
science.

Today,  ** _transformers eat everything_**  in and outside computer science -
by successfully deploying the foundational encoder/decoder deep learning
architecture.

_🍃 "Pangu-Weather is the first AI prediction model to demonstrate higher
precision than traditional numerical weather forecast methods. The model
allows a 10,000x improvement in prediction speed, reducing global weather
prediction time to just seconds."_

Check out the article for more!

Be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris



PS: Ben Fox (CEO Shepherd) invited me to share my three favorite books in
2023. Feel free to check them out [here]({Link}).

{'subject': "Why OpenAI won't be the next Google", 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

Here's a fun story I recently read: 👩‍🦳🚗

A wealthy woman goes to a new bank in downtown San Francisco.

She meets with a loan officer and asks to borrow $10,000.

The banker asks, _"What's the money for?"_

_"It's for a three-week vacation to Vancouver,"_ she replied.

**Banker** : _"What kind of security can you give us for the loan?"_

**Woman** : _"How about my new Rolls Royce? It's outside. I'll leave it with
you. That'll more than cover the $10,000."_

**Banker** : _"Yeah, that's more than enough security."_

After her vacation, the woman returns to the bank. She meets with the same
loan officer and repays the $10,000 plus the $49 in interest.

As she's about to leave, the banker asks, _"You're a wealthy woman. Why borrow
money for a trip?"_

The woman smiles, then replies, _"Where else in San Francisco can I safely
park a $350,000 Rolls for two weeks for only $69?"_

~~~

It wouldn't surprise me if the woman's skill of thinking outside the box, in a
first-principle, interdisciplinary way, was how she became wealthy in the
first place.

The woman is an intelligent _user_ of the system that leverages the system in
creative ways to maximize value.

With the rise of LLMs, this skill of _thinking outside the box_ has become
invaluable.

**Infrastructure vs Application: Who got richer, the founders of AT &T; or
Google? **

Similarly, the generative AI revolution will create far more value for
intelligent (=street smart) _users_ of the models that create higher-level
services as compared to the _providers_ of the model infrastructure.

For example, my bet is on Tesla with its _AI apps_ like self-driving and
humanoid bots, rather than NVidia as the _provider of AI infrastructure_ such
as chips and AI-training-as-a-service.

Infrastructure tends to become commoditized over time.

Startup.ai companies like Character.ai using LLM tools like Langchain will
create far more relative value compared to infrastructure companies such as
OpenAI.

Both AI application and AI infrastructure businesses may grow substantially.
But the outsized gains will be made by the AI application businesses where
owners think in interdisciplinary ways to create apps that actually bridge the
new technologies into the real world.

Discovering LLMs (Simon Willison calls it "[Alien technology]({Link})") is
like the discovery of electricity.

Now, more than 100 years after Nikola Tesla, Thomas Edison, and others
popularized the use of electricity, we're still developing applications on top
of it - such as the Internet, Bitcoin, or even LLMs.

And we're already developing new applications on top of Bitcoin and LLMs.
Progress often happens layer after layer after layer. One of the new base
layers of humanity is infinitely scalable intelligence.

For instance, we can now access powerful proprietary LLMs via API (e.g.,
[GPT-4-32k]({Link})) or offline, free, and open-source LLMs like [Llama
2]({Link}) or others:

  * [MPT-7B: A Free Open-Source Large Language Model (LLM)]({Link})
  * [The Open-Source Ecosystem Outruns Tech Giants: A Shift in AI Landscape]({Link})

The question now becomes how to integrate those models into real-world
applications.

Let me be blunt: **Don't waste your time trying to figure out the math and
theory of AI if you're not already an AI researcher and enthusiast. Instead,
focus on using LLMs in your particular area of expertise.**

For example, if you're working in packaging 😉, try fine-tuning a
[GPT-3.5]({Link}) model to handle common packaging queries in your business,
possibly reducing customer service overhead by 10%.

Or, if you're working in game design, can you integrate the most popular
personas from _character.ai_ into your RPCs to make your game world truly rich
in social experience?

These low-hanging fruits are everywhere now - ripe for the taking. And you
don't need to be an AI professor, either. Just be a curious and playful user
of the new tech.

You're just one intelligent prompt away from changing the world. 🤯

**TL;DR** : Moving forward, the application layer of generative AI will grow
even faster than AI infrastructure service providers. Think small and apply
LLMs to specific problems you face daily, rather than getting lost in AI mega
visions.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'A Short Primer on AI Scaling Laws', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

The AI scaling laws could be the biggest finding in computer science since
Moore’s Law was introduced. 📈

[[Blog] AI Scaling Laws – A Short Primer]({Link})

In my opinion, these laws haven’t gotten the attention they deserve (yet),
even though they could show a clear way to make considerable improvements in
artificial intelligence.

This could change every industry in the world, and it’s a big deal. Here are
three reasons why I believe the AI Scaling Laws are as important as Moore's
Law: 👇

  * **Accelerating Technological Advancements** : The scaling laws in AI could lead to rapid advancements in AI technologies, enabling breakthroughs in fields like natural language processing and robotics, much like Moore's Law did for computer chips.
  * **Economic Growth and Disruption** : Just as Moore's Law drove economic growth in the tech industry, the scaling laws in AI could lead to significant economic growth and disruption across various industries, as AI technologies automate tasks and create new business models.
  * **Societal Impact** : Similar to the societal impact of Moore's Law, the scaling laws in AI could have a profound effect on society, as AI technologies become more integrated into our daily lives, improving areas like healthcare and education.

Check out 🔗 [today's Finxter article]({Link}) on AI Scaling Laws.

Let's stay on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'Is Messi the Goat? A Python Puzzle', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

  
Hey {User},

Watching Messi videos with my son has revitalized my love for soccer.

~~(And I wonder if creating _"Best X Messi Goals"_ videos would've been the
better growth strategy for the Finxter Youtube channel 😅⚽ given that many of
these videos get tens of millions of views.)~~

So here's a new Finxter puzzle for you - can you solve it?

messi_goals = 30  
ronaldo_goals = 25  
neymar_goals = 15

if (messi_goals > ronaldo_goals  
or ronaldo_goals > neymar_goals  
and messi_goals + neymar_goals < ronaldo_goals * 2):  
result = "Messi = GOAT"  
elif (neymar_goals + ronaldo_goals < messi_goals * 2  
and messi_goals - ronaldo_goals < neymar_goals):  
result = "Messi goat"  
else:  
result = "Messi"

print(result)

You can check the result and explanation on the [Finxter puzzle app
here]({Link}).

Happy puzzling! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'AI COMPUTE MOONS 🧑‍🚀', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

A few days ago, I sent you a highly speculative [article]({Link}) on rumors
about OpenAI's breakthrough technology called _Q*_. I admitted that the
information was very thin.

But in a fresh exclusive with _The Verge_ , Sam Altman dropped the following
bombshell:

  * _**Interviewer** : The reports about the Q* model breakthrough that you all recently made, what’s going on there?_
  * _**Sam Altman** : No particular comment on that unfortunate leak. But what we have been saying — two weeks ago, what we are saying today, what we’ve been saying a year ago, what we were saying earlier on — is that we expect progress in this technology to continue to be rapid and also that we expect to continue to work very hard to figure out how to make it safe and beneficial._

In my logic: _**If Sam calls it a leak, it must be real.**_ (?)

Diving deeper into the topic, I found the following interesting nugget:

_"The [...] breakthrough allowed OpenAI to overcome limitations on obtaining
enough high-quality data to train new models [...] The research involved using
computer-generated [data], rather than real-world data like text or images
pulled from the internet, to train new models. That appears to be a reference
to the idea of training algorithms with so-called synthetic training data,
which has emerged as a way to train more powerful AI models." _\-- **Wired**

Like Tesla's new end-to-end full-self-driving (FSD) system, synthetic data is
now being used by OpenAI to train neural nets!

I share this with you because I believe the following take is not well-
understood by the general public:

  * The [AI Scaling Laws]({Link}) suggest we have **not reached saturation** in performance - all we need to do is throw more compute and more data on the problem.
  * Many argue that data is the limiting factor - e.g., in humanoid robotics, we don't have a lot of real-world data.
  * However, **if we can effectively train models on synthetic data, we've mitigated this bottleneck!**

We're already seeing a double-digit percentage productivity improvement for
our economy due to LLMs. This trend is sustainable for at least a couple of
years. Maybe decades!

Have a look at this research result in a recent first-class paper _"GPTs are
GPTs: An Early Look at the Labor Market Impact Potential of Large Language
Models"_ :

🧑‍💻 _"Our findings reveal that around 80% of the U.S. workforce could have at
least 10% of their work tasks affected by the introduction of LLMs, while
approximately 19% of workers may see at least 50% of their tasks impacted.
[...]" _

Another big takeaway is this: **when synthetic data is an effective option,
the bottleneck for AI will be _compute_.** Singularity will take our hunger
for compute to the moon.

10x, 100x, 1000x of demand for AI compute in a few years wouldn't surprise me
in the least.

Bullish for AI compute providers like NVDA, AMZN, and TSLA!

Be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

_It primarily sources environmental impact data from

_The GPT aims to inform users about sustainable diets with concise, clear, and

{'subject': '16 personality types for tech enthusiats', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

Management consultant Peter Drucker hammered it in my brain:

You. Can. Only. Perform. From. Your. **STRENGTHS.**

Roughly one hundred million (!) people have taken the Myers and Briggs
personality test. The 16personalities website ( _not affiliated_ ) is one of
the most viral websites out there.

**tl;dr:** You answer a couple of questions and the test assigns one of 16
different personalities to you based on the following four dimensions:

  1. **Extraversion (E) vs. Introversion (I):** Where do you direct your energy? Outwardly towards people and activities or inwardly towards thoughts and ideas.
  2. **Sensing (S) vs. Intuition (N):** How do you prefer to take in information? Through direct and concrete facts or by interpreting and adding meaning.
  3. **Thinking (T) vs. Feeling (F):** How do you prefer to make decisions? Based on logic and consistency or based on the people and special circumstances.
  4. **Judging (J) vs. Perceiving (P):** What's your preference when dealing with the outside world? With a planned and organized approach or a more flexible and spontaneous approach.

I found the test to be very robust. For example, no matter how often I repeat
the test - I've done it at least a dozen times over the years - it always
gives me INFJ (Advocate).

They may be right: I feel awful writing about this; the test lists as one of
my weaknesses to being "reluctant to open up".

Anyways, just for fun I've written a small online tool where you can put in
your personality type and it provides you with a possible career path in tech
(tech enthusiasts only!).

[[Online Tool] What’s Your Career Path Based on Myers-Briggs’ 16
Personalities?]({Link})

The "recommendation" is crude so don't take it too seriously. But if only ten
from 150,000 Finxters decide to adjust their career paths towards greater
authenticity, nothing would make me happier and the small effort was well-
spent.

Life is too short to do meaningless work that doesn't suit your personality,
especially with the rise of LLMs and AGI.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'Newsletter Update', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})



Hey {User},

As [LLMs]({Link}) generate abundant information, **scarcity** 💎 becomes more
and more valuable.

There's little value in working harder because we cannot possibly outwork
infinite computing.

Instead of

  * writing more code,
  * creating more content,
  * generating more noise,

we should do the opposite: **[Do less but accomplish more]({Link}). **

For example, [Tesla's new self-driving software system]({Link}) now comprises
only 3,000 lines of code instead of 300,000.

~~

💎 Pondering this, I decided to _**reduce** _the frequency of the Finxter
newsletter. 💎

Many other tech newsletters have increased their sending frequency these days,
generating more noise. But I don't believe more information serves you as a
reader in a [post-GPT world]({Link}).

I appreciate that your time is your scarcest resource.

To this end, let's start with a weekly email on Wednesday with some links to
relevant articles (like in this email). Depending on community interest, I
plan to add a weekly **Python Puzzle/Meme Friday** for fun and learning.

The value proposition for you is simple: Keep reading the Finxter newsletter
once per week and check out the linked articles to stay ahead in LLM, AI, and
exponential technologies. All while having some fun along the way.

Be on the right side of change. 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': '9 Finxter Articles - 2023 in Review', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

Thanks for being an avid reader of the Finxter newsletter. 🤗

_**For better or worse, 2023 has been a disruptive year for all of us.**_

Here's what we did in 2023 to help you stay on the right side of change:

  * published 1712 new [tech articles]({Link}), roughly five articles a day, thanks to many Finxter contributors. ♥️
  * reached more than 10 million people, many of them hundreds of times in 2023
  * welcomed more than 500 net new [premium members]({Link}) to the Finxter family while doubling average lifetime (~ _inverse churn rate_ ), a proxy for customer satisfaction
  * sent you north of 360 email updates on tech, LLMs, coding, and business - in 365 days
  * personally replied to more than 10,000 Finxters

Note that the year was not without struggle. Throughout 2023, I've thought a
lot about strategy on my daily walks. We changed the direction of the business
multiple times and needed to be nimble and adaptive amidst an explosion of web
content (and competition!) through ChatGPT.

Personally, I never missed a day in 2023 working on Finxter and publishing new
content: no sick leave, work-free weekends, or vacation breaks. I'm not the
most intelligent person in the room, but I'm dedicated, persistent, and
committed to your success.

Why? The Finxter mission of _**being on the right side of technological
disruption**_ has become my life's passion and I wouldn't miss a day!

But all of it wouldn't be possible without your valued time and attention.
Thanks! 🙏

Let's review the year with a few hand-selected articles published or updated
in 2023 on the Finxter blog.

  1. [What Would Jesus Say? Creating a ChatGPT Mastermind with Jesus, Gandhi, Musk, and Gates]({Link})
  2. [I Created a ChatGPT-Powered Website Creator with ChatGPT – Here’s What I Learned]({Link})
  3. [7 Effective Prompting Tricks for ChatGPT]({Link})

{'subject': 'What are embeddings in OpenAI?', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User}

Many (even sophisticated) OpenAI and Python API users don't understand
embeddings.

I think this is a huge miss - instead of feeding huge amounts of textual
contents into the model as context, they should use embeddings, i.e., vector
databases.

**[[Blog] What Are Embeddings in OpenAI?]({Link}) 🔢**

Embeddings, in the context of OpenAI, are numerical representations of textual
or code-based information. They convert concepts into number sequences, which
enables computers to comprehend the relationships between these concepts more
easily.

OpenAI’s embedding models, such as text-embedding-ada-002, have been designed
to outperform other top models in various standard benchmarks, including a 20%
relative improvement in code search performance.

**💡 Principle**

You should know that isn't proprietary to OpenAI, but rather a broadly
recognized principle within the machine learning field.

In a nutshell, when someone talks about _"computing the embedding of a text"_
, they're essentially converting that text into a unique numerical form.
However, this isn't just any number - it's a special kind of number that
allows arithmetic operations to be conducted with words or phrases, a task at
which computers excel.

**🧒 Child + ⏲️ Time = ?**

As an example, using embeddings, you could mathematically express something
like "child" + "time" equating to "adult" or "queen" minus "female" resulting
in "king".

I saw this example in a Reddit threat - lovely isn't it?

Another handy feature of these numbers is that you can use them to group alike
words together. For instance, "dog" and "puppy" would have numbers that are
relatively close to each other, but significantly distant from "submarine".

**🔍 Embeddings - Used for Search**

For users of Language Learning Models (LLMs) like ChatGPT, embeddings are
typically leveraged for search operations. Bear in mind that LLMs have finite
space for the input and output, often referred to as the context window,
meaning you can't process an entire book, for example.

If you wanted to extract information about the book, you'd divide it into
smaller sections that can fit within the context window, and then you'd follow
these steps:

1\. Compute the embedding for each section.  
2\. Once you've calculated the "number" (embedding) for each section, take the
user prompt and compute its embedding.  
3\. Next, compare the user embedding to the book section embeddings and
identify the closest one. Since these are numerical values, you can use a
mathematical function to determine their proximity (cosine distance is
recommended by OpenAI).  
4\. Now, you can pass the question to GPT, accompanied by the relevant section
that you've just identified.

This procedure is extremely useful and versatile, and can be implemented for
various data sources, including emails in your inbox, documents on your drive,
or even Amazon reviews.

I hope this explanation clarifies the concept for you!

**🚀 What's Next?**

Stay tuned for our upcoming emails on LLMs and exciting new tech developments.
🧑‍💻👩‍💻

And if you haven't already, check out our newly-launched course on advanced
prompt engineering (e.g., using embeddings) on the Finxter Academy:

[[Academy] Prompt Engineering with Python and OpenAI]({Link})

To your success! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'LlamaIndex - What the Fuzz', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

Imagine Albert Einstein is standing before you, ready to help you out.

Now if you ask Einstein a generic question like _"How can I stay relevant in
today's world?"_ , you'll get a generic answer.

Even Einstein's high-IQ brain needs relevant and fresh information about your
personal situation and the current context to give you a helpful answer.

_**Human Prompting 101**_

If you want to be a good human "prompter", you'll need to carefully inject
recent and relevant context to obtain the best answers from the biological
brains.

The same holds for prompting artificial brains like large language models
(LLMs): if you prompt an LLM with the right context data, you'll get vastly
better results.

**_But how to do it with Python?_**

Enter LlamaIndex.

Think of it as a helper library that allows you to feed ChatGPT with just the
right context from myriads of data sources in real-time—everything the LLM
needs to extract meaningful insights from data.

Just as scholars need both their inherent knowledge and the latest research to
provide the best answers, ChatGPT requires both its training and fresh data
from LlamaIndex.

Missing either the brain (e.g., ChatGPT) or the context (e.g., using
LlamaIndex) would be like trying to solve a puzzle with half the pieces. The
magic truly happens when they come together:

**High-Quality Data + High-IQ Brain**

In today's Finxter article, I'll give you a big-picture overview of LlamaIndex
because I found this was missing in their docs:

🦙 [[Blog] LlamaIndex – What the Fuzz?]({Link})

Now moving to a different Python library I found fascinating: Python's free
weather API that allows you to plot historical weather data from your
hometown:

🐍 [[Blog] Python Code for Getting Historical Weather Data]({Link})

Just for fun, you could even combine both:

Create a simple weather assistant chatbot based on LLM tech (e.g.,
GPT-3.5-Turbo) and feed it historical weather data from the API to provide
users with all kinds of weather information, even weather-, seasonal- and
location-based experience recommendations, in natural language.

LlamaIndex is powerful, you can plug any data source into any LLM! 🤯

It's a beautiful episode of tech disruptions we're currently experiencing!

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'Python + Financial Independence', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

In today's email, you'll improve your Python skills and get insight into a
coding millionaire's mindset.

Let's start with Python list comprehension, a powerful feature that allows you
to create lists dynamically in a single line of code:

🐍 [[Blog] List Comprehension in Python]({Link})

The blog also teaches you adjacent topics such as set comprehension,
dictionary comprehension, tuple comprehension, generator expressions,
filtering, nested list comprehension, and more.

I'm confident you'll find it valuable to improve your technical skills.

A wise strategy to survive the upcoming disruptions is to compound your
technical knowledge in small daily increments. Even with the rise of ChatGPT
and LLMs, technical skills in coding will help you become a 1% coder who can

{'subject': '🐍 Python Puzzles Challenge: Test Your Skills! 🧠', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

**1\. Healthy Habits 🚶‍♂️**

exercise_recommendations = "Walk 30 minutes daily. Drink 8 glasses of water.

**2\. Vitamin Boost 🍇**

fruits = ["apple", "banana", "cherry", "date", "elderberry"]  
vitamin_c_content = [5, 10, 7, 2, 60] # in mg per 100g  
high_vitamin_c_fruits = [fruit for fruit, content in zip(fruits,
vitamin_c_content) if content > 10]  
print(high_vitamin_c_fruits)

🔗 [Test Your Solution & See Explanation]({Link})

**3\. Mind and Body Balance 🧘‍♀️**

activities = ["running", "swimming", "yoga", "cycling", "meditation"]  
minutes_spent = [40, 30, 60, 20, 15]  
recommended = [activity for activity, minutes in zip(activities,
minutes_spent) if (activity == "meditation" and minutes >= 10) or (activity !=
"meditation" and minutes >= 30)]  
print(recommended)

🔗 [Test Your Solution & See Explanation]({Link})

Chris

{'subject': 'Bye Bye Elites 👋 ChatGPT Levels the Playing Field in Search Performance and UX vs Google Search', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User}

I just released a new tutorial on a brand-new paper (published today) that
shows the difference in performance and user experience of ChatGPT vs Google:

[[Research] Bye Bye Elites 👋 ChatGPT Levels the Playing Field in Search
Performance and UX vs Google Search]({Link})

**TLDR:**  
(1) Using ChatGPT outperforms using Google across study groups  
(2) ChatGPT levels the playing field, i.e., PhDs don't outperform high-
schoolers

[![](https://blog.finxter.com/wp-
content/uploads/2023/07/image-26-928x1024.png)]({Link})

Fascinating stuff considering there are a couple of low-hanging fruits for
ChatGPT, whereas Google Search is already optimized in every way imaginable.
Reminds me of the electric vehicle space compared to OEMs.

Some low-hanging fruits:

  * Improve speed by 10x so ChatGPT will feel much more intuitive and responsive.
  * Integrate with many apps and browsers (e.g., using plugins and functions) so ChatGPT will be 10x more useful.
  * Improve the chatbot performance (e.g., integrating real-time data) so ChatGPT output quality will increase by 10x.
  * Add multi-modality so ChatGPT input & output can be images, videos, audio.

Together, these and other improvements can easily result in multiple orders of
magnitude of performance improvement. ChatGPT will not only be faster and
produce better quality results but also feel much more natural.

I know many Googlers are reading this newsletter and hope that research papers
like these can escalate the urgency of pushing their UX to the next level - I
would prefer not to see Google falling for the innovator's dilemma.

If you're still interested in some fascinating new research papers, check out
the following fresh paper showing how Microsoft Research has applied ChatGPT
to robotics:

[[Research] ChatGPT Breaks New Ground in Robotics! This New Microsoft Research
Shows How]({Link})

To your success! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'Indie Devs Use This Game Plan to Make Millions', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User}

utility for devs:

[[Blog + Video] I Made a ChatGPT-Powered Logo Generator App Using Python Flask

Going through this 20-30 minute tutorial will be worth it for you because it
teaches you the new way to disrupt whole industries:

✅ **Step 1** : Build a simple frontent input

✅ **Step 2** : Use GPT-4 or other LLMs as intelligent backend (application
logic)

✅ **Step 3** : Monetize with freemium model

A small army of Indie devs like you and me is currently using this game plan
to capture increasingly large parts of the old economy.

The logo generator app is nothing fancy and it can be hacked together in a
couple of days (as a complete beginner). Yet it automates a small Fiverr niche
of low-quality cheap Fiverr logo designers and, thereby, creates real-world
value.

If your logo generator app replaced 10,000 low-quality logo designers
producing three logos per day for $30, it'll free up 10k designers * 365 days
* 3/day * $30/design = $328,000,000 of capital.

A fraction of the new value created will flow to the coder creating the app.

Hands-on coders and practitioners (like you?) currently disrupt myriads of
small and mid-sized industries with the help of ChatGPT, Midjourney, and
DALL-E.

The technical skills to do this are minimal.

{'subject': 'Smart Contracts on Bitcoin w/o Hard Fork - Dream or True?', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

I remember talking to a few colleagues about Bitcoin back in 2016.

As distributed systems researchers, we were genuinely excited about the tech.
What fascinated us was that it was now possible in a practical, real-world
system to find a majority consensus that tolerates a minority of nodes failing
or even trying to hack the system.

One of us mentioned that Bitcoin could be a good investment, but most rejected
the idea. Bitcoin - too obvious, old-school tech, and overhyped. A massive
bull run followed, increasing BTC's price by more than 30x.

Opportunity often hides in plain sight. Today, most people, even techies,
reject Bitcoin. I believe they will miss a similar bull run in the years to
come.

Today, we are deep in the bear market. The opening rates of all my Bitcoin
emails are low. Of course, this will change in the upcoming bull market. But
today, the early majority (~34%), late majority (~34%), and laggards (16%)
don't care about Bitcoin.

Yet - bullish news is building up:

Upcoming demand shock from the Bitcoin ETF, regulatory clarity, intangible
accounting rule change, increasing liquidity in global financial markets, a
record low of BTC supply on exchanges, federal chaumian mints, nation state
mining announcements, Lightning payments for LLM agents, and now this. 👇

[[News Article] BitVM – Smart Contracts on Bitcoin Without Hard Fork]({Link})

Under the radar of those who haven't followed the space closely during the
last few years, massive multi-party network effects from developers, miners,
politicians, citizens, and HODLers have been accumulated.

This new BitVM paper has opened up another universe for adopting "money over
IP". If you know Internet culture, you've read about protocol wars in the
1970s. The open-source, more decentralized protocol TCP/IP has won against
closed-source protocols pushed by more centralized entities like Cisco.

The Internet economy, a rapidly growing portion of global trade, will be built
on an Internet-native "money over IP" protocol. The transition is inevitable.
What technology will win?

Well, the answer is the same as in 2016: the largest, open-source,
decentralized "money over IP" protocol with the biggest network effects. We
shouldn't reject it only because it seems obvious.

Check out the new Finxter article to learn more about the most recent
breakthrough!

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'The Chain-of-Verification Prompting Tactic', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})



Hey {User},

Just stumbled on this new prompting technique developed by some researchers
from Meta AI and ETH Zurich: 👇

[[Blog] Chain-of-Verification: This Novel Prompting Technique Fights
Hallucinations in LLMs]({Link})

The idea is simple and makes sense from first-principles thinking. The
researchers are top-notch. So allow me to recap the 4-step prompting strategy
here quickly:

  1. **Drafting an Initial Response:** The language model drafts an initial response based on the input query.
  2. **Planning Verification Questions:** The language model then devises verification questions to fact-check its draft.
  3. **Answering Verification Questions:** These questions are answered independently to avoid bias.
  4. **Generating a Final Verified Response:** Utilizing the answers, the model refines its initial draft and generates a final, more accurate response.

As prompt engineers, we should build a mental library of these prompting
strategies. You never know if or when you'll come up with that million-dollar
prompt that disrupts an industry!

I believe the immediate future of high-performant LLMs will be **multi-model,
multi-modal systems** where multiple AIs or AI agents work together in a
dynamic pipeline of self-promptings to generate highly enriched answers that
outperform the prompting results of individual models.

That is -- at least until the one AGI model that rules them all rises from the
mountains of new AI research published daily. 🤖

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'Reverse Engineer Plots with Bard', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User}

Consider the following scenario I've often encountered as a coder:

Say you read a research paper, article, or book and you wonder how a certain
plot was made.

You cannot really use StackOverflow or even Google search for that...

When encountering this exact problem today, it became apparent to me that
there may be a simple solution:

I wondered if Google Bard can reverse engineer simple Python plots?!

📈 **My Input** : A screenshot of a plot (e.g., taken from a paper or report)

🤖 **Bard Output** : Python Matplotlib code

If you think about it, this is an insanely valuable use case for data
scientists! 🤯 So I've written a short blog guide on it:

👉 **Three examples** : [Towards Reverse Engineering Matplotlib Code From
Images]({Link})

I’m very impressed with Google Bard’s capabilities, and I’m sure they will
grow significantly over the next couple of months.

Google Bard can already match the capabilities of an entry-level data
scientist. You can already pass simple plots and let it reverse-engineer the
code that generated those plots.

Soon you’ll be able to pass arbitrary plot screenshots into it and let it
generate the code for you. This is six-figure-per-year work currently done by
advanced data scientists.

When I was still a researcher at University, I’d have done almost everything
for such a tool — given that most research papers live and die by the high-
quality plots they generate and most researchers and data scientists spend
huge amounts of time figuring out how others have generated their stunning-
looking plots.

Check it out and integrate this simple 3-minute trick into your daily practice
to save hours of plotting research in the future.

To your success! 🚀  
Chris

PS: If you run a tech startup or AI company, you seek more visibility for your
product, or you want to find top talent in the AI, programming, and tech
space, feel free to check out the [Finxter newsletter sponsorship]({Link}) we
have just launched.

{'subject': 'Passing Ten Papers In One Prompt', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User}

Have you already checked out the new large language model (LLM) everybody's
talking about?

Today I spent a few hours researching Claude 2, the newly-launched LLM from
Anthropic. (No worries if you don't know them - I didn't.)

Like ChatGPT, it can pass many human-centric tests such as grade school math
problem solving, Q&A; on very long stories, answering science questions, or
reading comprehension. And it beats most humans.

And like ChatGPT, Claude 2 can even pass the bar (lawyer) and the USMLE test
(medicine).

But unlike ChatGPT and most other open-source models, it can process 200k
token context data!! 🤯

You can get a quick overview on the Finxter blog:

🔗 [[Blog] Claude 2 LLM Reads Ten Papers in One Prompt with Massive 200k Token
Context]({Link})

Currently, US citizens can already try it out. You can upload your PDFs and do
all the fun stuff the rest of the world (*cough* Germany) cannot access yet
(*cough* without VPN).

Now you may wonder - is a 200k token (~150k words) context window large?

An average novel is around 80,000 to 100,000 words.

So, 150,000 words would be equivalent to a long novel or perhaps a trilogy of
shorter novels. For example, “Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix” by
J.K. Rowling is over 257,000 words.

My doctoral thesis was only 57k so you could load multiple Ph.D. theses into a
single prompt.

This is insane. And I don't understand why so many people try to tamper my
excitement - don't they get exponentials?

In fact, most humans would struggle if I handed them two Ph.D. theses and
asked them to write a detailed comparison. But all of this could be done in a
single 200k context window!

Check out the blog, charts, and Claude 2 model and stay tuned for tomorrow's
email where I'll show you another great tech achievement.

To your success! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'Early signs of singularity? 3 coping tips inside', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

Singularity is a point in time where technological growth becomes
uncontrollable and irreversible resulting in unforeseeable changes to human
civilization.

Many first-class computer scientists have expressed their support of the
thesis that "singularity is near".

**Ray Kurzweil** predicts paradigm shifts will become increasingly common,
leading to _"technological change so rapid and profound it represents a
rupture in the fabric of human history"._ In fact, Kurzweil predicted human-
level AI by 2029 which seems too conservative to me given the recent
advancements in LLM technology.

**John von Neumann** argues that the _"ever-accelerating progress of
technology and changes in the mode of human life gives the appearance of
approaching some essential singularity in the history of the race beyond which
human affairs, as we know them, could not continue."_

**Irving Good** who worked with **Alan Turing** on Bayesian statistics and
cryptography speculated that an intelligence explosion will happen as follows:
_"Let an ultra-intelligent machine be defined as a machine that can far
surpass all the intellectual activities of any man however clever. Since the
design of machines is one of these intellectual activities, an ultra-
intelligent machine could design even better machines; there would then
unquestionably be an 'intelligence explosion', and the intelligence of man
would be left far behind."_

**Stephen Hawking** worried that _"The development of full artificial
intelligence could spell the end of the human race. It would take off on its
own, and re-design itself at an ever-increasing rate. Humans, who are limited
by slow biological evolution, couldn't compete, and would be superseded."_

Okay, I'm more optimistic. Positive change in the AI space is not slowing
down. It accelerates. For instance, here are some news headlines that I
collected during the last couple of days:

  * _**Tesla's Optimus** robot can now sort objects autonomously using an end-to-end neural network system similar to the groundbreaking full self-driving system presented earlier this month._
  * _Amazon is investing up to **$4 billion in[Anthropic]({Link})**._
  * _**ChatGPT is getting multi-modal** capabilities, allowing users to speak to the model, have it speak back, and upload images for questions._
  * _**Spotify introduces AI-powered voice translation** for podcasts using [OpenAI's Whisper]({Link}), maintaining the original voice in translations._
  * _**ChatGPT** helps diagnose tethered cord syndrome in a boy, highlighting AI's potential in [**medical applications**]({Link})._
  * _**OpenAI announces DALL-E 3** with enhanced features and integration with ChatGPT._
  * _**Google's Bard chatbot now offers a "double-check"** feature to enhance accuracy and accountability._

In today's email, I want to share three _"coping mechanisms"_ to help you
thrive in the upcoming decades.

**✅ First, you can be certain about one thing: change.**

Stay open-minded, set aside daily time to learn, apply, and play with new
technologies such as those mentioned above.

To help you stay on the right side of change, we'll be here with Finxter
during the next decade or so with small daily doses of tech knowledge.

**✅ Second, you strive to be an owner not merely a user of new technologies.**

Technological disruption will create an abundance of many things but it will
inherently flow to the owners of the technology first.

Investing in scarce desirable assets will remain a great idea.

The [scarcest and most desirable asset]({Link}) is Bitcoin. The infinity of AI
meets the scarcity of Bitcoin. Supply is fixed and demand will explode so you
figure out my price expectations for BTC: 📈

**✅ Third, focus on love and lasting relationships instead of work.**

Much of the work you're doing today will be done by robots tomorrow. Why
bother sacrificing quality time with your family just so you can cram in a
little bit of additional work?

Just use LLMs for automation, cut your work time by half, and let the machines
do your job better than you could. A single intelligent prompt you create at
the right time and the right location could accomplish more than a lifetime of
unskilled labor.

Again focus on being an owner and early user of new tech. Don't focus on being
a working bee. There's little reward for being a hard worker in a fully
automated factory. But there is a significant reward for being the owner and,
possibly, designer of this same factory.

Let's be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris

{'subject': 'We are not our jobs --- but who are we?', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

The future of work is uncertain and our careers, as we know them, are at risk
of disruption.

We all feel it.

Here's what I struggle with these days: I've interwoven too much of my self-
worth and identity with my perceived contribution to society. Machines doing
more and more of that heavy lifting keeps undermining my feeling of self-
worth:

_Why am I here?_

Millions of Finxters struggle with the same question, consciously or
subconsciously.

So, allow me to make explicit what is often missed due to it being too
obvious:

**⭐ Our job roles should _not_ be the source of our self-esteem or worthiness.
⭐**

Associating our self-worth with our work is a precarious position to be in, as
it makes us vulnerable to external changes. If our self-worth is too deeply
intertwined with our job, any threat to that job can feel like a personal
attack, leading us to either resist change or feel lost and devalued when
change is inevitable.

Consider retirement as an example.

It's often observed that people, particularly men, face a crisis of identity
and purpose post-retirement. This can lead to serious health implications -
even earlier deaths soon after their well-deserved retirement.

_"If we are not needed, why live at all?"_

Legions of men focus all their effort, energy, and self-worth on career
success rather than quality relationships. And more and more women are
starting to repeat that same mistake.

You are not your job. As we detach our self-worth from our job roles, we
become more resilient to such transitions.

By perceiving our career not as a defining part of our identity but rather as
a dynamic and enjoyable game, we open ourselves to new opportunities. This
approach increases our psychological safety, making us more adaptable and
efficient.

When we view technologies such as LLMs as tools to play with rather than
threats to our jobs, we can disrupt our own roles in positive ways, leading to
greater success and fulfillment.

_**So, where should we draw self-confidence and identity from if not from our
jobs?**_

The answer, in my opinion, is profound:

If somebody loves you, you are still needed by them.

If you have loving relationships, your feeling of self-worth becomes
antifragile against disruptive change. More robots and AI agents lead to
higher productivity, which reduces the need for human work.

Let's take the PoV of the older man or woman you will be. You'll most
certainly regret not spending more time with your loved ones. You won't regret
spending less time at work - especially as machines disrupt your work.

The singularity is here, and it'll gift us flexibility and freedom. We should
embrace it not as a threat but as an exciting opportunity for growth and focus
on what truly matters in our lives - quality relationships, love, and health.

From this perspective, disruptions help us obtain _more_ confidence and self-
worth.

As individuals, I believe it's best if we reach the mindset that technological
disruption is just a multiplayer game providing us with magical items and
alien tech LLMs to level up our gameplay.

This not only safeguards our mental and emotional well-being but also
positions us on the right side of change, ready to thrive in an ever-evolving
world.

Be on the right side of change. 🚀  
Chris

seriously.

{'subject': 'Sorry we wasted your time', 'body': '[![]({Link})]({Link})

Hey {User},

While walking today, I remembered my lovely days as a University student.

_... Sitting on the floor due to overcrowded lecture halls, listening to
theoretical computer science professors who had already lost 90% of the
students after 10 minutes of talking ... 🎶_

Here's a provocative question: Why is it common practice to waste students'
time in many universities?

Shouldn't students be treated more like valued customers rather than unwelcome
disturbances from the _real_ work (=research)?

While I cannot speak for all people in academia, I'm definitely guilty even
though I love teaching: my strategy to catch up with pressing research tasks
was to **avoid teaching effort as much as humanly possible**.

In hindsight, two features were missing for an efficient and modern learning
experience:

  1. A pause button ⏹️, and
  2. A personal tutor I could ask "dumb questions" right when I lost the plot while everybody waits until I get it.

Fortunately, you can now get what I couldn't! That's why I've spent my
afternoon today (and $500 per month on OpenAI tokens) launching FinxterGPT on
the Academy:

🧑‍💻👉 [https://academy.finxter.com/]({Link})

[![](https://blog.finxter.com/wp-
content/uploads/2023/11/FinxterGPT_Academy_4.gif)]({Link})

If you're a premium member, you can now pause each [Finxter Academy]({Link})
course video and ask GPT-4 Turbo for clarification or even code right where
and when you need it. 🤩

And if you're not a premium member, you can still use Finxter GPT-4 Turbo on
any [blog]({Link}) post, but with lower priority and slightly more token
restrictions.

Be on the right side of change! 🚀  
Chris
